And na mare sal travayle bot ay reste,
Als þai war sette at þe bigynnyng,
When God made þam and alle thyng;
Þai war þan, als men may trow,
Mykel brighter þan þai er now.
Þe movand heve[n]s with-outen dout,
Sal þan ceese o turnyng obout,
And na mare obout in course wende,
For of alle thyng þan sal be made ende.
Þe movand hevens now obout gas,
And þe son and þe mone þair course mas;
And þe othir planetes ilkane,
Moves als þai þair course haf tane;
And alle þe elementes kyndely duse
Þat þat es nedeful til man use.
Þus ordaynd God þam to serve man,
Bot of alle swylk servise þai sal ceese þan.
For alle men aftir domesday
Sal be war þai sal duelle for ay,
Þe gude in blis, in rest and peese,
Þe ille in payne þat never sal ceese.
What nede war þat þa creatures þan,
Shewed swilk servyse mare for man.
Na qwik creature sal þan be lyfand,
Thurgh out þe werld in na land,
Ne nathyng sal growe þan, gresse ne tre,
Ne cragges ne roches sal nan þan be,
Ne dale, ne hille, ne mountayne;
Bot alle erthe sal be þan even and playne,
And be made als clere and fayre and clene,
Als any cristal þat here es sene;
For it sal be purged and fyned with-oute,
Als alle other elementes sal be oboute,
And na mare be travayled oon na side,
Ne with na charge mare occupide.
Now haf yhe herd me byfor rede
Of þe day of dome þat many may drede,
And of þe wondirful takens many,
Þat salle falle byfor þat day namly,
And how þe werld þat we now se,
Aftir þe dome als new made sal be,
Als here es contened, wha-swa wille luke,
In þe fifte part of þis buke;
Here on now wille I na langer stande,
Bot ga til þe sext part neghest folowande,
Þat specialy spekes, als writen es,
Of þe paynes of helle þat er endeles,
ÞatBot (MS. Harl. 4196). alle men, þat here lyfe byhoves lede,
Aght specialy mast to drede;
For þa paynes er swa fel and hard,
Als yhe sal here be red aftirward,
Þatilk man may ugge, bathe yhunge and alde,
Þat heres þam be reherced and talde.

DIV1.HEAD: Her begynnes þe sext party of þis boke þat spekes of þe paynes of Helle.This heading is absent from MSS. Galba E IX, Harl. 4196).

LG.L: Many men here spekes of helle,
Bot of þe paynes þar fune can telle,
Bot wha-swa here mught wit and k[n]aw wele
What paynes þe synful þar sal fele,
Þai suld in grete ferdlayk be broght,
Ay when þai on þa paynes thoght;
For þe mynde of þam myght men feer,
Swa bitter and swa horribel þai er;
Bot forþi þat many knawes noght right,
Whatkyn paynes in helle er dight,
With-outen ende for synful men,
Þarfor I sal shewe yhow, als I can,
Aparty of þa paynes sere,
Als yhe may sone aftirward here.
Bot first I wille shew whare es helle,
Als I haf herd som grete clerkes telle,
And sythen wille I shew yhow mare,
And speke of þe paynes þat er þare.
Som clerkes says, als þe buke bers witnes,
Þat helle even in myddes þe erthe es;
For alle erthe by skille may likend be
Til a rounde appel of a tre,
Þat even in myddes has a colke,
And swa it may be tille an egge yholke;
For als a dalk es even Imydward
Þe yholke of þe egge, when it es hard,
Ryght swa es helle pitte, als clerkes telles,
Ymyddes þe erthe and nourwhar elles.
And als þe yholk ymyddes þe egge lys,
And þe white obout on þe same wys,
Right swa es þe erthe, with-outen dout.
Ymyddes þe hevens þat gas obout.
Þus may men se by an egge hard dight,
How heven and erthe and helle standes right.
Ful hydus and myrke helle es kyd,
For-why it es with-in þe erthe hyd,
Þider þe synful sal be dryven,
Als tyte als þe last dome es gyven.
With alle þe devels ay þar to duelle,
Þat now er in þe ayre and in helle,
Þar sal þai alle be stoped togider;
Wa sal þam be þat sal wende þider,
For þar es swa mykel sorow and bale,
And swa many paynes with-outen tale,
Þat alle þe clerkes þat ever had wytt,
Þat ever was, or þat lyfes yhitt,
Couth noght telle ne shew thurgh lare,
How mykel sorow and payne er þare.
And if it thurgh kynd myght be swa,
Þat an hundreth thousand men or ma,
Had an hundreth thousand tunges of stele,
And ilk tung mught speke wysely and wele
And ilka tung of ilka man,
Had bygunnen when þe werld bygan,
To spek of helle, and swa suld speke ay
Whils þe werld suld last til domes day,
Yhit mught þai noght þe sorow telle,
Þat to synful es ordaynd in helle;
For-why na witt of man may ymagyn
What paynes þar er ordaynd for syn.
Bot men may fynd, wha-swa wil loke,
Som maner of paynes wryten in boke,
Omang all other paynes þat er in helle,
Als men has herd wyse clerkes telle;
Bot what man es swa wyse and wytty
Þat couthe telle þa paynes proprely,
Bot it war he þat had bene þare,
And sene þa paynes bath les and mare?
Bot he þat þar commes for certayne,
May noght lightly turne agayne;
He most duelle þar and never oway com,
For pe buke says þus of wysdom:
Þat es on Ynglisse "men knawes nane,
Þat turned fra helle þat þider was gane."
For alle þat er þar most duelle for ay,
Þai may never be broght oway,
Bot-if war thurgh miracle anely,
And thurgh specyal grace of God almyghty,
Thurgh whilk som, þat in helle has bene,
And horrible paynes þar has sene
Has bene broght oway fra alle þat stryf,
And bene turned ogayne fra ded til lyf;
Als Lazar was Mary brother Maudalayne,
Þat saw and herd þare many a payne,
Þat tyme namely when he was ded,
For his saul þan was at þat sted,
Four dayes, als God vouched save,
And swa lang his body lay here in grave;
And at þe last God raysed hym ryght
Fra ded til lyf thurgh his myght;
Bot þat þat he saw he noght forgatt,
And sone þare-after als he satt
With Crist at þe meete in Martha hows,
He talde a party of þa paynes hydus;
Bot yhit durst he noght al telle,
For drede of Crist, þat he saw in helle,
Yhit lyfed he after fyften yhere,
Bot he lugheloghe (MS. Harl. 4196). never, ne made blythe chere,
For drede of dede þat he most efte dreghe,
And of þe paynes þat he saw with eghe.
For how bitter þe dede es nan may witt,
Bot he anely þat has feled itt,
And what paynes in helle er, nane wil wene
Bot he anely þat has þam sene.
Alswa twa of Symeon sons ryght,
Þe whilk Caryn and Lentyn hight,
When þa first war dede and hethen went,
Þai saw in helle many a tourment,
And sithen when Crist dighed on þe rode,
Þai rase fra ded and obout yhode,
And tald how Crist, byfor þat he ras,
Til helle come and tuke out þat his was,
And mykel couthe þai þan telle
Of þe paynes þat þai saw in helle.
Bot þai had no leve als I wene
To telle alle þat þai þar had sene;
Wharfor þai lyfed here ay in penaunce,
And never aftir made blithe countinance,
Of wham es writen in a pistel þus,
Þat Pilat sent til Tyberius,
Þat þan emparour of Rome was,
For to certifie hym of þis cas.
And yhit many other þat war dede,
Has bene sumtyme at þat stede,
And sene þar many hydus payne,
And thurgh miracle turned til lyf agayne;
Bot omang alle þat þar has bene sene,
I fynde wryten paynes fourtene,
Thurgh whilk þe synful sal be pyned ay,
In body and saul aftir domesday;
Þe whilk er als general paynes of helle,
And whilk þas er I sal yhow telle.
Þe first es fire swa hate to reken,
Þat na maner of thyng may it sleken.
Þe secunde es calde als says som,
Þat na hete of fire may overcom.
Þe thred alswa es filthe and stynk
Þat es stranger þan any hert may thynk.
Þe ferthe es hunger sharpe and strang.
Þe fift es brynnand threst omang.
Þe sext es swa mykel myrknes,
Þat it may be graped, swa thik it es.
Þe seve[n]d es þe horribel sight
Of þe devels þat þar er hydusly dight.
Þe eghtend payne es vermyn grete,
Þat þe synful men sal gnaw and frete.
Þe neghend es dyngyng of devels hand,
With melles of yren hate glowand.
Þe tend payne es gnawyng with-in
Of conscience þat bites als vermyn.
Þe ellevend es hate teres of gretyng,
Þat þe synful sal scalden in þe dounfallyng.
Þe twelfte es shame and shenshepe of syn
Þat þai sal haf þat never sal blyn.
Þe threttend es bandes of fire brinnand,
Þat þai sal be bunden with fote and hand.
Þe fourtend payne despayre es cald,
Þat þe synful sal ay in hert hald.
Alle þir er generale paynes in helle;
Bot þar er other ma þan tung may telle,
Or hert may thynk or eer may here,
Of special paynes þat er sere,
Þe whilk many, aftir þai er worthy,
Sal thole ever-mare in saule and body;
Bot of alle þa paynes can I noght say,
For na man þam reken ne specyfy may,
Bot yhit wille I speke som-what mare
Of þe general paynes þat I shewed are,
And with som autorities þam bynd,
Als men may in sere bukes writen fynd.
Þe first als I tald es þe fire hate,
Þat na thyng may sleken ne abate;
Whare þe synful men sal bryn thurgh hete
Of whilk God spekes þus thurgh þe prophete:

L.HI1: meo, et ardebit usque ad in|

LG.L: "Fyre es kyndeld in my wreth", says he,
"And sal bryn until ende of helle sal be,
Þat es ever-mare, als God vouches save,
For helle sal never-mare ende have."
Þat fire es swa hate, and ay brynnes,
Þat if alle þe waters þat standes or rynnes
On erthe, and alle þe sese with-oute,
Þat encloses alle þe erthe oboute,
Suld ryn in-til þat fire swa hate,
Yhit myght it noght it sleken ne abate,
Na mare þan a drope of water shire
If alle Rome brend, mught sleken þat fire.
For þe fire of helle þat es endeles,
Es hatter þan fire here es,
Right als þe fire þat es brinnand here,
Es hatter and of mare powere,
Þan a purtrayd fire on a waghe,
Þat es paynted outher heghe or laghe,
With a rede coloure til mens sight,
Þat nouther brynnes ne gyfes light,
Ne on othir manere avales ne ders.
Of þir twa fires I fynde writen twa vers.

L.HI1: Quam focus est mundi picto fervencior igne,
Tam focus inferni superat fervenicia mundi.

LG.L: "Als þe fire of þe werld hatter es
Þan a fire paynted, be it mare or les,
Rightswa þe fire of helle passes thurgh hete,
Alle þe fires of þe werld, smale and grete,
And for-þi þat þe synful brynned ay here,
In þe fire of fole yhernyngs sere,
It es right þat þai brynne þare
In þat hate fire for ever-mare.

L.HI1: "Est locus indignis ubi non extinguitur ignis,
Non qui torquetur, nec qui torquet, morietur."

LG.L: Þe secunde payne es grete calde,
Þat þe synful sal fele, als I ar talde;
Þat cald sal be swa strang and kene,
Þat if þe mast roche þat man has sene,
Of þe mast mountayne in any land,
War al attanes in fire brynnand,
And even Imyddes þat cald war,
It suld frese and turne al in-til yse þar;
And for-þi þat þai, omang other vice,
Brynned ay here in þe calde of malice,
And ay was dased in charité,
Þarfor it es right þat þai be
In þat strang calde ever-mare lastand,
Whar þai sal frese, bathe fote and hand.
Þe devels sal tak þam fra þat fire,
And cast þam, with ful grete ire,
In-til þat cald to eke þair payne,
And efte þam cast in þe fire ogayne;
Þus sal þai cast þam to and fra,
And ever-mare þai sal fare swa.
Of þis þe haly man bers wittenes
Iob þat says þus, als writen es:
"Fra waters of snawes þe synful sal wende
Til þe over mykel hete þat has nan ende."
And Saynt Austyn says on þis manere,
In a buke, als es writen here.

L.HI1: exterius calore ut ferum in for|

LG.L: "Þe wikked sal outwith be glowand
Thurgh hete, als men in fire brynnand,
And with-in thurgh calde sharpe and kene,
Als yse þat es in wynter sene,"
Þus sal þai ay be in calde and hete;
Þis tourment es ful strang and grete.
Þe thred payne es, als men heres clerkes telle,
Þe grete stynk and filthe þat es in helle;
Of þis Saynt Ierom, þe haly man,
Says þus, als I here shewe yhow can:
"Þe fire es þar of swa grete pousté,
Þat it may never mar slekend be,
And swylk filthe and stynk es in þat ugly hole,
Þat nan erthely man mught it thole;"
For na man in erthe may ymagyn
Swa mykel filthe, als sal be þar-in,
Whar-for þar sal be mare stynk
Þan tung may telle or hert thynk.
Þe whilk stynk, with filthe and fen,
Sal be strang payne til synful men,
And yhit þe fire þat bryn þam sal,
Sal gyfe a st[r]ang stynk with-alle,
For it sal be fulle of brunstane and pyk,
And of other thyng þat es wyk;
And for þe synful delyted þam here namly,
In þe filthe and stynk of lechery,
It es right þat þai be ay omang
Þe stynk and filthe in helle swa strang.
Þe ferthe payne es, als I haf herd say,
Þe strang hunger þat þar sal last ay,
Þe whi[l]k þe synful in helle sal fele,
Ever-mare als þir clerkes knawes wele.
Þe strenthe of hungre sal þam swa chace
Þat þair awen flesshe þai sal of-race;
And for hungre þai sal yherne it ete,
For þai sal gett nan other meete;
For hungre þai sal be als brayne-wode,
Bot þe dede þar sal be þair fode,
Als says þe prophet in a stede:
'Þai sal be fedde with þe dede:'
Þis es on Inglys þus to rede:
"Þe dede þam sal dolefuly fede."
For als he þat has here hungre grete,
Thurgh kynde langes mast aftir mete,
Right swa þe synful þat sal duelle þare,
Yhit sal lange aftir þe ded wel mare
Þat þai mast hated and drede here,
Bot dighe may þai noght on na manere,
Of þis Saynt Ion bers wittnes,
Als in þe apocalipse writen es:
"Yherne þai sal to dighe fra þair wa,
And þe ded sal ay fle þam fra;"
And forþy þat þai wald gyf na mete
Til þe poer, þat here hunger had grete,
Ne of þam had nouther reuthe ne mercy,
Bot used ay outrage and glotony,
It es right þat þai haf þis payne
Grete hungre in helle ay þar ogayne.
Þe fifte payne es, als sal befalle,
Grete threst þat þai sal haf with-alle,
Swa mykel in helle sal be þair threst,
Þat þair hertes sal nere cleweclefe (MS. Harl. 4196). and brest;
Bot þe flaume of fire þai sal drynk,
Menged with brunstan þat foul sal stynk,
And with smoke of fyre and wyndes blast,
And with other stormes þat ay sal last,
Þat alle togider þan sal mete;
And þarfor says David þe prophete:
He says þus, als we writen fynde,
"Fire and brunstan and stormes with wynde,
A part sal be þar of þair drynk,"
And þat sal be menged with smoke and stynk;
Yhit sal þai drynk, ogayne þair wille,
Another manere of drynk þat es ille,
Þat sal be bitter and venemus,
And be cald þair wyne, for þe prophet says þus:

L.HI1: Fel draconum vinum eorum, et venenum

LG.L: "Galle of draguns þair wyne sal be,
And wenym of snakes þar-with," says he,
"Þat may noght be heled wele,"
Swa violent it es to fele.
Þir wordes, aftir þe lettre, er hard to here,
Bot men may þam take on othir manere.
Þai sal swa brynnand threst thole,
Þat þair hertes sal bryn with-in als a cole,
For na licour sal þai fynd to fele,
Þat þair threst mught sleke and þair hertes kele;
Þai sal for threst þe hevedes souke
Of þe nedders þat on þam sal rouke,
Als a childe þat sittes in þe moder lappe,
And when it list, soukes hir pappe;
For I fynd þis word in haly writt,
Als Iob says þat witnesses it:
"Þe heved of nedders þat on þam sal fest"
He says, "þai sal souke þan for threst."
Strang payne of threst þan haf þai
When þai sal souke for therstthrest (MS. Harl. 4196). swilk venym ay.
And for-þi þat þai wald never blethely
Gyf til poer at drynk þat war thresty,
To sleken þair threst, ne on þam thynk,
Ne nouther gyf þam mete ne drynk,
And on þair-selven na drynk wald spare
Na day, til þai drunken ware,
It es þan right þat þat þai in helle fele
Brynnand threst þat never sal kele;
Þat sal þai haf when þai com þider,
And sharp hungre alswa bath to-gydre,
Þat never sal cesse, als I sayde ar;
For þir twa paynes with othir er endel[e]s þar,
Of þis Saynt Ierom bers wittnes,
Þat says þus, als writen es:
"In helle sal be whar never es rest
Endel[e]s hungre and endeles threst."

L.HI1: Inferni pene sunt hec, vermes, tenebreque
flamma, chorus demonum, fetor, frigusque fa|mes, sitis, horror.

LG.L: Þe sext payne es over mykel myrknes,
Þat in helle sal be ay endeles;
Þat swa thik es þat men mught it grape,
Fra whilk þe synful sal never eschape.
For na hert may thynk ne tung telle,
Swa mykel mirkenes als es in helle,
Of whilk Iob spekes, als þe buk shewes wele,
And says, þe synful sal grape and fele
Myrkenes, als mykel at mydday
Als at mydnyght, þat sal last ay:
"In helle es never day bot ever nyght;
Þar brynnes ay fire, bot it gyf[es] na light."
Bot yhit þe synful sal ay se
Alle þe sorowe þat þar sal be,
And ilka payne and ilka tourment,
Thurgh sparkes of fire þat obout sal sprent.
Bot þat sight sal be til þam þare,
Na confort, bot sorowe and kare.
Þus to eke þair paynes, þai sal haf sight,
With-outen any comfort þar of light;
And for-þi þat helle es ay lightles,
It es cald þe land of myrkenes,
Þat es depe and myrke and hydus,
Þarfor says Iob, þe haly man, þus:
He says; "Loverd þat I noght turne away
Til þe myrke land", whare sorow es ay,
Whare wonyng es ay hydus and ille,
Als Iob says þat þus spekes mar þar-tille:
"Þar nan ordre wonand es," says he,
"Bot uglynes þat ever mare sal be."
And forþi þat þe synful in þair lyf here,
Lufed ay myrknes of syns sere,
And wald noght turne þam when þai myght,
Fra þat myrknes til Goddes light,
It es right þat þai duelle þare,
In þat hidus myrknes ever-mare,
And never-mare aftir light se;
A strang payne til þam þat sal be.
Þe sevend payne es of þe fourtene
Þe sight of devels þat sal be sene
Omang þe synful þat sal be in helle,
In whas company þai sal ay duelle.
Þat sight sal be swa hidus to se,
Þat alle þe men of cristianté
Couthe noght, thurgh witt, ymagyn right,
Ne descryve swa hydus a sight,
Als þai þan sal se in helle ever-mare,
Of ugly devels þat sal be þare,
For þan sal be ma devels in helle,
Þan any tung can reken or telle;
And ilkan sal mare grysely seme
Þan any man can ymagyn and deme:
For swa hardy es na man, ne swa balde
In þis werld, nouther yhung ne alde,
If he myght right consayve in mynde,
How grysely a devel es in his kynde,
Þat durst for alle gude of mydlerde
A devel se here, swa suld he be aferde;
For þe hardyest man in flesshe and bane
Þat here lyfes, yf he sawe ane
Of þa devels in þair awen lyknes,
Suld wax wode for ferde and be wittles.
For-why na witt of man may endure
To se a devel in his propre figure.
How sal þai fare þan þat ay sal þam se,
And ay in company with pam be?
Þe synful sal ever-mare on þam luke
For þus we fynde wryten in boke:

L.HI1: In inferno videbunt eos, facie ad faciem,

LG.L: "In helle þai sal þam se, face to face,
Whas werkes þai lufed and folowed þe trace,
Whilles þai war here in erthe lyfand;"
And with þat syght, als I understand,
Þai sal duleful crying and sorow here,
For Saynt Austyn says on þis manere:
"Þai sal se þar devels with eghe,
Thurgh sparkes þat of þe fire sal fleghe,
And here þar-with on ilka party,
Þe wreched synful grete and cry."
And þe sorow and dule þat þai sal make,
Sal never-mar þar cees ne slake;
And forþi þat þat here hated to se,
And to here þat þat gude suld be,
And þarfor it es reson and ryght,
Þat þai ay se þat grysely syght,
And þat þatþai? heryng haf of duleful dyn,
To eke þair payn for þair sin.
Þe aghtend payne, als þe buke says us,
Es þe horribel vermyn venemus.
Þe whilk sal on þe synful rouke,
And ever-mare þam gnaw and souke,
Als ugly draguns, and nedders kene;
And tades swa hydus was never here sene
And othir vermyn ful of venym,
And wode bestes grysely and grym,
Þat with tethe sal with þam ay gnaw and byte,
On alle þair lyms, whar þai had delite
Synful werkes here for to wirk,
Agayne þe law of God and of haly kyrk.
Þus for þai did ay ogayns Goddes lawe,
Vermyn and wode bestes sal þam ay gnawe,
For þair syn þat þam thoght here swete,
Þarfor God says þus thurgh þe prophete:

L.HI1: Dentes bestiarum immittam in eos, cum furo|
re trahencium in terra atque serpencium.

LG.L: "I sal send in þe synful", says he,
"Þe tethe of bestes þat felle sal be
With wodenes of þam in-til crthe drawand,
And of nedders þam fast gnawand."
Þus sal wode bestes and vermyn gnaw þam ay
And never-mare pas fra þam oway;
And þat payne þe synful byhoves ay dreghe,
For-why þair vermyn sal never dieghe,
Bot ever-mare lyfand with þam duelle,
Þarfor God says þus in þe godspelle:
"Þair vermyn salle never deghe," says he,
"Ne þair fyre salle never slekend be;"
And to þat says þus Saynt Austyne,
Þat spekes here of þat vermyne:

L.HI1: Vermes infernales sunt immortales qui, ut pis|
ces in aqua, ita vivunt in flamma.

LG.L: He says, "vermyn of helle salle ay lyfe,
And never deghe þe synfulle to gryefe,
The whilk salle lyfe in þe flawme of fyre,
Als fyssches lyfes in water schyre."
Þat vermyn on þam salle ay crepe,
In þam fest þair clokes full depe;And in þaim feste þair clowes ful depe (MS. Harl. 6923).
Þai salle umlapp þam alle oboute,
And gnaw on ilka lym and souke;
With vermyn þai salle alle coverd be,
Swa þat na lym of þam salle be fre,
And swa þai salle be ay gnawand
On þair lyms, whether þai lyg or stand;
Vermyn in helle salle be þair clethyng
And vermyn salle þare be þair beddyng.
Na clathes þai salle have to gang in,
Ne na beddes to lyg in bot vermyn,
Wharfor I fynd wryten þare I have red,
How þe prophete discryved swilk a bed
To þe kyng Nabogodonosor,
And sayd þus to mak him ferd þarfor:
He says "of wormes þi bed salle be
Þat salle be strewed thyk under þe,
And þi covertoure on þe sene
Salle be vermyn fulle felle and kene."
Swilk beddes er ordaynd in helle
Ffor synfulle men þat þar salle dwelle.
Þus salle þai be pyned for þair syn,
Ever-mare with fyre and vermyn,
And with many other payns ma;
Ffor God vouches safe þat it be swa,
Ffor þus fynd we wryten in haly wrytt,
In a boke of þe Bibelle þat hate Iudyth:
It says "fyre and vermyn þat ay salle lyfe,
Our lord tylle þe flesch of synfulle salle gyfe,
Swa þat þai salle bryn ever-mare,
And ay fele of vermyn bytyng sare."
Þis payne es mare to fele and se,
Þan alle þe paynes þat may be
In þis werld here, mare and les,
Als þe boke openly bers witnes,
Þus salle vermyn in helle be gret payne,
Bot yhit may men say here ogayne,
Ffor men may in som boke wryten se
Þat after þe gret dome þat last salle be,
Na quyk creature salle lyf þan,
Bot anely aungelle, develle and man,
'How suld in helle þan or ourwhare elles,
Any vermyn lyf als men telles,
Or any other best þat moght dere?'
To þis may men gyf answere
On þis manere, wha-swa kan;
Þe vermyn þat salle be þan,
Als I understand, noght elles es
Bot devels in vermyn lyknes,
Þat salle byte and gnaw þe synfulle þare,
To eke þair payne and mak it mare.
Þus salle þe devels gnaw þam with-out,
In lyknes of vermyn alle obout.
And þair conscience als vermyn,
Salle gnaw þam over-alle with-in,
And þat gnawyng salle be fulle hard,
Of whilk I salle speke sone afterward.
Þat vermyn in helle salle be mare grysely
Þan vermyn here es, and mare myghty.
By vermyn here þan þat greves sare,
Men aght to drede þe vermyn þare;
And forþi þat þe synfulle was here namely,
Ay fulle of hateredyn and of envy,
And wald noght amend þam of þat syn,
Bot lete it gnaw þam ay with-in,
It es ryght and skylle thurgh Godes lawe,
Þat þe vermyn in helle ay þam gnawe.
Þe neghend payne es to understand,
Dyngyng of devels with hamers glowand;
Ffor þe devels þe synfulle salle ay bete
With glowand hamers huge and grete
And als smyths strykes on þe yren fast,
Swa þat it brekes and brestes at þe last,
Right swa þe devels salle ay dyng
On þe synfulle, with-outen styntyng;
And with hamers gyf swa gret dyntes,
Þatalle to powdre moght stryke hard flyntes;
Ffor harder dyntes gaf never engyne,
Þan þai salle gyf, als says Saint Austyne:

L.HI1: mo asperius et crudelius, corpora malorum

LG.L: He says "als men may se ane engyne cast,
And at þe walles of a castelle stryke fast
With a stane þat es huge and hevy,
Swa salle devels stryke þaseþuse? mare felly
Þe ille bodyse and saules þat salle dwelle,
After þe last gret dome in helle."
Þus salle þai dyng on þam ever-mare,
With gret glowand hamers, and nane spare.
And þis payne tylle þam salle be endles,
Als þe bok here-of bers witnes;
Ffor þai salle have power ay and leve,
Þe synfull men to dyng and greve,
Als in a boke es schewed tylle us,
Þat Saynt Austyne made, þare he says þus:
"Þe domes salle þan be redy
Tille þe sklaunderers of God alle myghty,
And tylle þase þat salle be ay smytand
Þe bodyse of synfulle with melles in hand."
And forþi þat þai wald noght take
Haly disciplyne here, for Godes sake,
Þarfor þe devels salle stryk þam þare,
With hevy melles ay, and nane spare.
Þe tend payne es þe gnawyng with-in
Of þair conscience þat never salle blyn;
Ffor with-in þam salle þe worme of conscience frete
Als with-outen salle do vermyn grete,
And swa salle þai ever-mare, with-outen dout,
Be gnawen and byten with-in and with-out.
Ffulle mykelle sorow salle þan be in helle
Omang þe synfulle þat þare salle dwelle;
Ffor þai salle ever þus cry and say,
'Allas! Allas! and walaway!
Whi ne wald we never are trow,
What payne and sorow here es now.'
Þan salle þai pleyne þam of þair wickednes,
And say þus, als in boke wryten es:

L.HI1: Quid nobis profuit superbia, quid divicia|
rum iactancia, omnia transierunt velud um|
bra, et tanquam nuncius percurrens, et tanquam
na vis procedens in fluctuantem aquam, et tan|
quam avis transvolans in aere, cuius itineris non

LG.L: "What avayld us pryde", þai salle say,
"What rosyng of ryches or of ryche aray?
Alle þat pomp als we se now,
Es passed oway als a schadow,
And als messanger bifore rynand,
And als schypp þat gase in water flowand,
And als foghel fleghand in þe ayre als wynd,
Of whase gate men may na trace fynd."
Þus salle alle þair pomp oway pas,
And be als thyng þat never was,
Þan salle þam thynk when alle es oway,
Alle þair lyfe here bot als ane howr of a day,
Þof þai never so lang had lyfed here,
Þai may say on þis manere:
'Right now born we war in þe world to be,
Ryght now in alle our delytes lyfed we,
Ryght now we deghed and passed oway
Now er we in helle and swa salle be ay,'
Þan salle þai knaw how ille þai haf lyfed,
When þe worme of conscience þam has greved,
Þat with-in salle þam ay gnaw and byte
Ffor þai in vanyté had here delyte,
And for-þi þat conscience styrd þam noght,
To forsake þair folyes þat þai wroght,
Bot folowed ay here þair flesschly wille;
Þarfor it es gud, ryght, and skylle,
Þat þe worme of conscience with-in,
Ever-mare in helle þam gnaw for þair syn.
Þe ellevend payne es teres of gretyng
Of þe synfulle þat, with-outen styntyng,
Sal grete ever-mare, als says þe boke;
Ffor-whi what for sorow, and what thurgh smoke
And what thurgh cald, and what thurgh hete
Þat þai salle thole, þai salle ay grete,
And þus teres fra þair eghen salle ryn
Ever-mare and never salle blyn.
Swa mykelle water als salle falle þan,
Ffra a mans eghe may gesce na man;
Ffor-whi þai salle ay be gretand,
And þair teres salle be ay flowand,
And fra þair eghen ryn swa fast,
And þair gretyng swa lang salle last,
Þat in alle þe world here, als I wene,
Es noght swa mykelle water sene,
Als fra þair eghen salle falle þare;
Ffor þai salle be gretand ever-mare.
Wharfor Saint Austyn says þus,
Whase wordes er auctentyke tylle us:
"In helle," he says, "out-yhetted salle be,
Ma teres þan dropes er in þe se,"
Þe synfulle salle þare þus ever-mare grete,
And þair [teres] salle be of swa gret hete,
Þat þe water þat þan salle doun-ryn,
Ffra þair eghen, salle þam schald and bryn,
Ffor it salle be hatter þan ever was
Molten led or welland bras,
Als I have herd gret clerkes telle,
Þat has descryved þe payns of helle;
And for-þi þat þai had here ay lykyng
In þair syn and never forthynkyng,
Ne sorow þarfore, for þam thoght it swete,
Þarfor þai salle in helle ay grete,
And with þair teres be schalded sare,
To eke þair paynes, als I sayd are.
Þe twelfte payne es schame and schenshepe,
Þat þe synfulle salle have in helle swa depe,
Of ilka syn þat ever þai dyd;
Ffor-whi þare salle be knawen and kyd
Alle þair syns of thoght, or word and werk,
Als says Saint Austyne þe gret clerk:

L.HI1: Omnia in omnibus patebunt, et se ab|

LG.L: "Alle þair syns in þam salle shewed be
And þai may nouther þan þam hyde ne fle."
Þai salle have mare schame of þair syn þare,
And þair schendschepe salle be mare,
Þan ever had any man here in thoght
Ffor any velany þat ever he wroght,
And þat schame with þam salle last ay,
And never salle pas fra þam oway;
Þai may say þus þat þare þan dwelles,
Als þe prophete in þe psauter telles;

L.HI1: Tota die verecundia mea contra me est, et

LG.L: Þat es, "my schamefulnes," says he,
Alle day es ogayns me,
And þe schenschepe of my face
Salle cover me, in ilka place."
Þai salle swa schame ay of þair syn,
Þat þam salle thynk als þai suld bryn,
Ffor þe gret schame þat þai salle have þare,
Þat never salle cese, bot last ever-mare;
Wharfor if na payne war in helle,
Bot þat schame anely, þat I of telle,
It suld be tylle þam þare mare payne,
Þan any man couth here ordayne;
And forþi þat þai here in þair lyfe,
Durst never for schame of syn þam schryve,
Bot with-outen schame to syn was bald,
It es ryght þat þai have, als I tald,
Schame in helle for þair syn,
Of whilk þai wald here never blyn.
Þe threttende payne es, als clerkes wate,
Þe bandes of fyre brynand fulle hate,
With whilk þe synfulle salle be bonden,
Als in som boke wryten es fonden;
And þa bandes of fyre salle never slake.
Ffor þai wald never þair syn forsake,
Þai salle be with þa bandes brynand,
In helle hard bonden, both fote and hand,
And straytely streyned ilka lym,
Thurgh þe devels þat er ugly and grym.
Þair wonyng in helle salle be endeles,
Omang stynk and fylth in gret myrknes,
Whare ever es nyght and never day,
Als men may here gret clerkes say.
Þan salle þai fele, when þai þare come,
Godes vengeance thurgh ryghtwise dome,
Ffor þair syn þat him here myspays,
Wharfor God þus in þe gosspelle says:
"Lat bynd þair hend and þair fete fast,
And in-to þe utter myrknes þam cast,"
Þat es in þe deppest pytt of helle,
Whare mare sorow es þan tong may telle.
Þare salle þair hevedes be turned dounward,
And þair fete upward bonden hard,
And þair bodyse be streyned bi fete and hed,
With brynand bandes glowand red;
Þai salle be pyned on þis manere,
With other paynes many and sere,
Als a gret clerk says openly,
In a boke þat he made thurgh study,
Of sere questyons of divinité,
Þat es cald 'Flos Sciencie'
Þat es on Ynglys 'þe flour of konyng'
Whare wryten es many privé thyng;
In þat boke þus he telles,
How þai salle hyng þat þar þan dwelles:

L.HI1: Capita, inquit, eorum erunt ad-invicem deorsum versa,
pedes sursum erecti, et undique penis distenti.

LG.L: He says "in þe grond of helle dongeoune
"Þe hevedes of synfulle salle be turned doune,
And þe fete upward fast knytted
And in strang payns be streyned and tytted."
And for-þi, þat þai war here ay redy
To syn, with sere lyms of þair body,
Þarfor þai salle be bonden þare
Be divers lyms, als I sayd are,
With brynand bandes hate glowand,
Þat ever mare salle be lastand;
And for-þi þat þai wald noght God knaw,
Na kepe þe ordre here of his law,
Bot turned þam ay fro God-ward,
And on þe world þair hertes sett hard,
And swa mysturned here þair lyfyng
In-tylle vanyté and flesschly lykyng,
Þarfor it es ryght and resoune,
Þat þai be turned up-swa-doune,
And streyned in helle and bonden fast,
With bandes of fire þat ay salle last.
Þe fourtende payne es despayre to telle,
In whilk þe synfulle salle ay dwelle,
With-outen hope of mercy þan,
Ffor Salamon says þus, þe wise man:

L.HI1: Omnes qui ingrediuntur ad infernum non rever|

LG.L: He says "alle þase þat tylle helle wendes,
And in despayre salle be omang fendes,
Salle never after turne ogayne,
Ne tak þe ways of lyfe certayne."
For when þai er dampned thurgh iugement,
And with body and saule tille helle er sent,
Þai salle never after, with-outen dout,
Have hope, ne thynk to com out,
Bot ever-mare dwelle with-outen hope,
Ffor þus says þe haly man Job:
"Ffor in hell", he says, "es na redempcyoune"
Thurgh na help of frende; for na devocyone
Of prayer, ne almusdede, ne messe,
May þam help, ne þair payn mak les.
A strang payn salle þis be in helle,
Ever-mare þus in despayre to dwelle,
With-outen hope of recouverere.
Þis passes alle þe payns of þis lyfe here,
Ffor here has na man payn swa strang,
Þat he ne has som tyme hope omang,
Outher of remedy þat men may kast,
Or þat it salle end and noght ay last;
Elles suld þe hert, thurgh sorow and care,
Over-tyte fayle, warn som hope ware;
Ffor in sorow here hope comfortes best.
And men says, warn hope ware it suld brest.
Bot in helle na hope may falle in thoght,
And þair hertes brest may noght;
Ffor þai er ordaynd to lyf ay þare,
Swa þat þai may be pyned ever-mare.
Bot þe lyfe of þam in þat stede
Es wers and bytterer þan þe dede.
Bot better it war to be fully slayne,
Þan over-lang lyfe in strang payne;
Bot þe synfulle salle ay þare in payne be,
And na ded may þam sla bot ay þam fle,
Als þe boke openly schewes us,
Whare we may fynd wryten þus:
"Þe ded", þat here es strang and hard
"Salle ay þan fle fra þam-ward,"
Þe payns of þe ded þai salle ay dreghe,
Bot þai salle never-mare fully deghe;
Þai salle ay lyf in sorow and stryfe,
Bot þair lyf salle seme mare ded þan lyfe;
Þair lyfe in mydward þe ded salle stand,
Ffor þai salle lyfe ever-mare deghand,
And deghe ever-mare lyfand with-alle,
Als men dose þat we se in swowne falle;
And for-þi, þat þai here mykelle lufed syn,
And thurgh over-mykelle hope ay lyfed þar-in,
And to leve þair syn had never wille,
Þarfor it es gud, ryght and skylle,
Þat þai be ay for þair foly,
In helle with-outen hope of mercy.
Now have I schewed yhow, als I couth telle,
Þe fourtene generalle payns in helle;
Bot yhit es over þase a payne generalle,
Þat of alle other es mast principalle,
Þat es tharnyng for ever of the syght namly,
Of our Lord God alle-myghty.
Ffor whilk syght þat þai for ever have tynt,
Þai salle have sorow þat never salle stynt;
And þe sorow þat þarfor salle falle
Salle be mast payne to þam of alle,
For als þe syght of God in heven, es
Mast ioy of alle other, mare and les,
Right swa þe tharnyng for ever of þat syght,
Es þe mast payne in helle dyght;
Ffor alle þe payns þat in helle may be,
Suld noght þam dere if þai moght him se.
Yhit salle þare be sere payns many ma
Als þe boke says, and mare sorow and wa
Þan alle þe men of erth, ald and yhong,
Moght thynk with hert or telle with tong,
Þat þe synful men þat salle wende
Tille helle salle have with-outen ende,
Þe whilk payns and sorow salle never cees;
Ffor þare salle never be rest ne pees,
Bot travail and stryfe with sorow and care,
Fulle wa salle þam be þat salle dwelle þare;
Þai sall thynk on nathyng elles,
Bot on þair payns, als som clerkes telles,
And on þair syn þat þai here wroght,
Swa salle payns and sorow troble þair thoght;
Ffor þare salle be þan herd and sene,
Alkyn sorow and trey and tene.
Þare salle be wantyng of alkyn thyng,
In whilk moght be any lykyng,
And defaut of alle thyng þat gud moght be,
And of alle þat ille es gret plenté.
In helle salle be þan fulle dolefulle dyn,
Omang þe synfulle þat salle dwelle þar-in,
Þat ever-mare salle þus cry and say:
"Allas, allas and walaway!
Þat ever we war of wemmen borne,
Ffor we er fra God for ever lorne?"
Þan salle þai grete and goule and with teth gnayste
Ffor of help ne mercy þar þam noght trayste.Þai salle gret and with teth gnayste, For mercy þar þaim nane traiste (MS. Harl. 6923).
Þe devels obout þam þan in helle,
On þam salle ever-mare rare and yhelle;
Swa hydus noyse þai salle þan make,
Þat alle þe world it moght do qwake,
And alle þe men lyfand þat herd it,
To ga wode for ferd and tyne þair witt.
Þe devils ay omang on þam salle stryke,
And þe synfulle þare-with ay cry and skryke;
Þare salle be þan mare noyse and dyn,
Þan alle þe men of erth couth ymagyn,
Ffor þare salle be swilk rareyng and ruschyng
And raumpyng of devels and dyngyng and dusching
And skrykyng of synfulle, als I said are,
Þat þe noyse salle be swa hydus þare,
Omang devels and þase þat salle com þider,
Ryght als heven and erth strake togyder.
Ane hydus thing es it to telle
Of þe noyse þat salle þan be in helle;
Þe devels, þat ay salle be fulle of ire,
Salle stopp þe synfulle ay in þe fyre,
Swa þat þai salle glowe ay als fyre brandes
And ay when þai may weld þair hands,MS. Harl. 6923 reads styr for weld.
Ffor sorow þai salle þam hard wryng;
And walaway þai salle ay syng.
In helle salle be þan swa gret thrang,
Þat nane may remow for other ne gang.
On na syde, backward ne forward
Ffor þai salle be pressed togyder swaharde,
Als þai war stopped togyder in ane oven,
Ffulle of fyre bineth and oboven;
Bot never-þe-les helle yhit es swa depe,
And swa wyde and large, þat it moght kepe
Alle þe creatures, les and mare,
Of alle þe world if myster ware.
Ilka synfulle salle þare on other prese,
And nane of þam salle other eese,
Bot ever fyght togyder and stryfe,
Als þai war wode men of þis lyfe,
And ilk ane scratte other in þe face,
And þair awen flessch of-ryve and race,
Swa þat ilk ane wald him self fayn sla,
If he moght, swa salle him be wa,
Bot þare-to salle þai haf na myght,
Ffor þe ded salle never mar on þam lyght.
Ffulle fayn þai wald þan ded be,
Bot þe ded salle ay fra þam fle;
After þe ded þai salle yherne ilk ane,
Als in þe apocalypse schewes Saint Iohan:
"Þai sall yherne", he says, "to deghe ay,
And þe ded salle fle fra þam oway;"
Omang þam salle ay be debate,
Ilk ane of þam salle other hate.
Þai salle be fulle of hateredyn þan;
Ilk ane salle other wery and ban,
And say "cursed kaytif and wa worth þe,
And weryed mot þou ever be,
And weryed mot þai be ever-mare,
Þat þe gat and þat þe bare,
And þe tyme þat þou was born alswa,
Ffor þi payne es tylle me sorow and wa;
It pynes me and greves me sare,
Als mykelle als myne awen payn or mare,
Ffor my payne it ekes, and mase mare grevus."
Ilk ane tylle other þan salle say þus.
Þus ilk mans payne salle other dere,
And nane of þam salle other forbere;
Nouther son, ne doghter, ne syster, ne brother
Ffader ne moder, ne yhit nane other;
Ffor ilk ane salle other hate dedly,
And ilk ane gryn on other and cry.
Ilk ane salle gnaw þair awen tonges in sonder,
And ilk ane salle þare on other wonder.
Þus in helle salle þai far ay,
And þar-with sklaundre God and say:
"Whar-to made God us tylle his lyknes,
And lates us now dwell þare sorow ay es;
Bot it semes þat God made us in vayne,
When we er þus putted tille endles payne,
Or he us made for noght els to dwelle
In erth, bot to be fyre brandes in helle."
Þai salle wery þe tyme þat þai war wroght,
And say "allas whine war we noght."
Þus salle þai sklaundre God omang,
Swa hard þair payns salle be, and swa strang;
Þai salle ilk ane on other stare and gryn,
Als wode men dose here, and makes gret dyn;
An hydus thing to here it ware,
Wha-swa couth telle þe payns þare,
Als properly als þai salle þare be.
Bot þat couth noght alle þe men of cristianté.
Ne alle þe clerkes þat ever had witt,
Sen þe world bigan, ne þat lyfes yhit
Couth never telle, bi clergy, ne arte
Of þa payns of helle þe thowsand parte.
Ffor þe noumbre of payns þat þare griefes
Passes þe mens witt þat here liefes,
Or þat ever lyfed in any degré,
And þat may men bi skylle þus se;
Ffor ilka syn þat þe synfulle has wroght,
Whar it never swa lytelle venyalle thoght,
Þai salle have certayne payne þare,
After þat þe syn es les or mare.
Wha couth þan telle, war he never swa wyse,
Alle þe syns and alle þe folyse,
Both dedly and alswa venyale,
And leve nane untald, gret ne smale,
Þe whilk a man has here fallen in,
Ffra þe tyme þat he first bigan to syn,
Both in thoght, in word and dede?
Alswa say nane es þat tyme couth rede.Als wha say na man couth thaim rede (MS. Harl. 6923).
And for ilka thing done here in vayne,
In helle es ordaynd certayne payne
Tille synfulle men þat salle dwelle þare.
Þan bihoves þam, als I sayd are,
Ffor ilka syn þat þai dyd here,
Have certayne payne singulere;
And for ilka manere of syn and foly,
Be pyned in helle specyaly.
And als oft-sythe als þai here newed þair syn
Als oft-syth þair payn salle new þare bigyn;
Þarfor swamany payns tylle þam salle falle,
Þat na witt may comprehende þam alle;
Ffor na syn þat þai ever here dyd,
Dedly ne veniele, salle be hyd,
Bot alle openly sene and nan be laynd,
Ffor whilk salle be þare sere payns ordaynd;
Wha moght þan alle þe payns telle,
Þat þe synfulle men salle have in helle?
Ffor-whi if a man fra hethen pass oway
In a dedly syn, at his last day,
Ffor ilka venyel syn, þat ever dyd he,
He salle þan diversly pyned be;
And als oft renoueldrenewed? salle be ilk payne,
Als he turned new tylle ilk syn ogayne.
And þe lest payne þare es mare to se,
Þan alle þe payns of þis world may be,
Ffor alle þe payns of þis world here,
Þat ever was sene fer or nere,
Als to þe lest payne þare moght noght be tald,
Bot als a bathe of water, nouther hate ne caldAls a leuke bath nouther hate ne calde (MS. Harl. 6923).
Ffor alle þe sorow of þis world, ilka dele,
War noght bot als solace and ioy to fele,
Als to regard of þe lest payne,
Þat es in helle; þis es certayne,
Ilk synfulle salle haf syght þare
Of alle þe payns, both les and mare,
Þat alle þe synfulle men salle dreghe.
Þan salle ilk ane se þare with eghe
Men and wymmen, many a thousand,
On ilk syde obout, in sere payns dwelland;
And þat syght, þat ilk ane salle þare se
Of ilka payne, tylle þam payne salle be;
Ffor alle þe payns þat salle falle tylle ilk man
Salle be sorow tylle alle þat sese þam þan.
Þus salle ilk ane dreghe mare payn in helle,
Þan hert moght ever think or tong telle;
What of payns þat to þam-self salle be dyght,
And what of payns þat þai salle have of syght.
Ffor alle þe payns, þat þare salle be knawen,
Salle greve ilk man als mykelle als his awen;
Swilk payns to here, als men may here rede,
Aght to mak ilk man of helle have drede;
For I trow þat here es no man lyfand,
Swa hard-herted, þat wald understand
And trow what payns in helle er wroght,
Þat he ne suld have gret dred in thoght,
Þe whilk suld mak him hate alle foly,
Wharfor he war swylk payns worthy.
Bot alle þase þat wille þair syn forsake,
Whils þai lyfe here, ar þe ded þam take,
And of alle thing have forthynkyng
Þat þai have done ogayns Godes bydyng,
And turn þam tylle God fra þair syn,
And ask his mercy and trayst þar-in,
And be lufand un-tylle him and bowsom,
In þa payns of helle salle never com,
Bot tylle þe blys of heven mon þai wende,
And have þare þair lykyng with-outen ende.
Here have I spoken of þe payns of helle,
Als yhe have herd me openly telle,
And of þe sext part of þis boke made ende.
Now wille I tylle þe sevend part wende,
Þat es þe last part of alle;
Þe whilk spekes als I shew yhow salle,
Specialy of þe ioyes in heven,
Þat er mare þan any tong may neven.
Bot fyrst I wille schew yhow whare heven es,
Als clerkes says and þe boke bers witnes;
And efter þat I salle schew yhow mare,
And telle yhow of sere ioyes þat er þare.

DIV1.HEAD: Here bygyns þe sevend part of þis boke Þat es of þe ioyes of heven.

LG.L: Many þe blys of heven covaytes,
Bot fone þe ryght way þider laytes;
And som thurgh syn er made so blynd,
Þat þe right way þider þai kan noght fynd,
Som wald be þare, with-outen dout,
Bot þai wille noght travaille þare obout;
Bot whasa wille tak þe way þider-ward,
Behoves in gud werkes travaille hard;
Ffor tylle þe kyngdom of heven may no man com
Bot he ga bi þe way of wisdom;
Þe way of wysdom es mekenes
And other virtuse, mare and les.
And þat way es cald a gastly way,
Bi whilk men suld here travaille ay,
Þat es þe way þat ledes men even
Untylle þe hegh kyngdom of heven.
Bi other way may nane, bot he fleghe,
Pass up tylle heven it es swa heghe;
Ffor it es þe heghest place þat God wroght,
And þe first, when he made alle thing of noght.
Na man may gesce swa lang space,
Als es fro hethen untylle þat hegh place;
Ffor bitwene us and þat heghe heven
Es alle þe firmament to neven,
ÞeÞat? clerkes bi skylle hevens calles,
Þe whilk er ay moveand als falles.
Þus er oboven us hevens sere,
Bot alle er þa noght olyke clere;
Ffor þe heghest heven es wele bryghter
Þan þe other hevens þat er lagher;
Ffor þe heghest has swa mykelle bryghtnes,
And swa fayre and swa delytable es,
Þat alle þe men of erth couth noght
Swa mykelle ymagyn, ne think in thoght.
Sere hevens God ordaynd for sere thyng,
Bot þe heghest God made for our wonyng.
Þese hevens er oboven us heghe,
Als clerkes says, þat er wise and sleghe;
Ane es, þat we þe sterned heven calle,
Þare þe planetes and þe sternes er alle,
Þat men may se here, on nyght, schyne;
Ane other es, þat clerkes calles cristallyne,
Þat next oboven þe sterned heven es,
And es mare þan þat of wydenes;
Som clerkes it calles on þis manere;
Þe water heven, þat es als clere
Als cristalle, þat hoves oboven þare,
Ryght als water þat frosen ware;
Þus telles Berthelemewe in þe boke
Of propertes of sere thinges to loke:
Þir twa hevens ay obout-rynnes,
Both day and nyght, and never blynnes;
Þe erth, þat þa hevens obout-gase,
Es bot als a poynt Imyddes a compase;
Swa lytelle it es semand with-out
To regard of þa hevens obout;
And Imyddes þe erth es ordaynd helle,
Þare þe synfulle, þat salle be dampned salle dwelle
Als men may before rede and se,
And lawer þan helle may na place be;
Þus both þe hevens obout-gase ay
And never salle ceese untylle domesday;
Ffor clerkes says þat knawes and sese,
Of þir twa hevens þe propertese,
Þat if þai moved noght, alle suld peryssch,
Both man and beste, foghel and fyssch
And alle þat under þam may be,
Þat lyves and growes, both gresse and tre,
All suld be smoredAl schulde be spilt wyth-outen doute (MS. 22283). with-outen dout,
Warne þa hevens ay moved obout;
Ffor if þai stode never swa schort while stylle,
Alle þat on erth es suld perysch and spylle;
Þus telles gret clerkes of clergy,
Þat has bene lered in astronemy
And knawes þe constellacyouns
And þe heven þat þe erth envirouns.
Of þair moveyng þan have yhe no wonder,
Ffor it noryssch[es] alle þat es þare-under,
In wate and drye, in hate and cald,
Ay whils þai move, als I bifore tald,
Þir hevens obout-gase alle erthly thynges
And þam norysches and forth-brynges,
Ffor als clerkes says þat to þam tentes
Þai tempre þe streng[t]he of alle þe elementes
Ay als þai move whils þai obout-ga.
Bot þe thred heven es oboven þa twa,
Swa wonderly heghe and swa ferre
Þat nathyng may be heghere;
Yhit som clerkes ma hevens nevens,
And says þat þare er other seven hevens,
Þat semes lawer, als men may se,
Þan þe twa hevens falles to be,
Ffor-whi þe clerkes þe planetes alle
Bi certayne skylle hevens þai calle.
And seven planetes er oboven us;
Ffyrst þe Mone and Mercury and Venus,
Sythen þe Son and þan Mars and Iubiter,
And Saturnus oboven þan þat es hegher.
Ilk ane þair course obout ay mase
In þair cercles, als God ordaynd hase;
Þai styk noght fast, als smale sternes dose,
Ilk ane his course mase thurgh use;
Ilka planete falles for to be
Hegher þan other in ordre and degré;
Þe Mone, þe fyrst and lawest, es sene,
And Saturnus þe heghest es, als I wene;
Oboven us er alle þe planetes seven,
And þe cercle of ilk ane es called ane heven
Þat er wonderly bryght and fayre;
Yhit ane other heven es called þe ayre
Þat es lagher, þar þe foghles has flyght,
And þat heven es mast nere our syght
Bot it es noght swa clere ne clene
Als þe other hevens oboven er sene:
Alle þe cercles of þe planetes alle
Þat we here clerkes þus hevens calle,
Er bryght and clere, als þe bokes schewes us
And ilk planete es ferrer þan other fra us;
Ffra þe erth untylle þe cercle of þe mone, es
Þe way of fyve hundreth wynter, and na les,
Þat es als mykelle space at say,
Als a man moght ga, in playne way,
In fyve hundreth yhere fully,
If he moght lyfe swa lang in body,
Als a gret philosiphir þat hyght
Rabby Moyses telles ryght
Þat thurgh witt mykelle couth se;
And over þat alle, swa says he,
Þat ilka cercle þat es sene
Of ilka planete, may contene,
Als men may fynd wryten here,
Þe way of fyve hundreth yhere
Als es gesced in brede and thyknes,
Swa mykelle and thyk ilk ane es,
Þat es at say, als mykelle space here
Als a man moght ga in fyve hundreth yhere.
Þof þat travaille him suld noght gryfe
If he here swa lang moght lyfe;
And fra þe poynt of þe erthe tille Saturnus
Þe heghest planete may be gesced þus,
Þe way of seven thowsand yhere
And thre hundreth, als es wryten here,
Þat es at say, als es here contende,
Als mykelle space als a man moght wende
In seven thowsand yhere, andin? playn way gang
And th[r]e hundreth, if he suld lyf swalang;
Swa þat ilk yhere be acounted halely
Of thre hundreth days and fourty,
And þat þe way of ilka day
Be fully of fourty myle of way,
And þat ilka myle fully contene
A thowsand pases or cubites sene.
Raby Moyses says alle þis,
Þat er noght alle my wordes bot his;
Bot whether alle þis be soth or noght,
God wate, þat alle thyng has wroght,
Ffor he made alle thyng thurgh myght and sleght
In certain noumbre and mesure and weght;
Bot swa sutelle and wise may na man be,
Þat þat mesuryng knawes swa wele als he;
Ffor na thyng þat may be, mare or les,
Or þat ever was, tylle him unknawen es;
Himself fra erth, upward met þat way,
When he stey tylle heven on halghe Thursday,
Þat wate he best thurgh wytt and sleght,
What space þat way contened of heght.
Bi alle þe hevens had he gane,
And passed alle þe sternes ilk ane,
And up tylle þe heghest heven he went,
And alle þis way he passed in a moment,
In þe heghest part of þe sterned heven.
Oboven alle þe planetes seven,
Standes swa many sternes smale,
Þat na man may þam telle bi tale,
Þat standes fast þare, als þe buke pruves,
And er led obout with þe heven þat moves,
Als nayles er in a whele with-out,
Þat with þe whele er turned obout;
Bot þe planetes er noght led swa,
Ffor in þair cercles obout þai ga.
Þe sternes semes smale, als we deme,
Bot swa smale er þai noght als þai seme,
Ffor þai er schewed fra us swa fer,
Þat we may noght se how mykelle þai er;
Bot þe lest sterne þare þat we on-luke.
Es mare þan erth, als says þe boke;
Ffor clerkes says, if alle erth in fyre ware,
And possibel war þat a man war þare,
Him suld thynk, þof it bryned bryght,
Les þan þe lest sterne þat schynes on nyght,
Þan aght þat heven gret space contene,
Þare swa many sternes may be sene.
Alle þir hevens here sene may be,
Bot þe alther-heghest heven may na man se.
Tille þat heven couth na clerk thurgh arte,
Þe space gesce bi ane hundreth thowsand part
Ffor it es swa heghe, als Sydrak says,
Þat if a stane þat war of pays,
Of ane hundreth mens lyftyng,
Might falle fro þeþen, it suld be in fallyng
A thowsand yhere and na les,
Ar it come at þe erth, swa heghe it es;
Bot aungels þat fro heven er sent,
May com doune tylle erth in a moment,
And up ogayne tylle heven may flegh,
In þe space of a twynkellyng of ane eghe.
And swa may a saule þat es clene and lyght,
Com þider fro hethen in als schort a flyght,
Thurgh þe myght of God and thurgh noght elles
And swa has done many þat þare dwelles;
Þis may be halden a gret ferly,
Omang alle þe wonders of God alle-myghty,
Þat ane aungelle may pass swa many myle,
Ffra heven tylle hyder, in swa schort awhyle.
And a saule thurgh Godes myght and grace,
May fro hethen com þider in swa short space.
This heven es þe alther-heghest place of alle,
Hegher es na thyng þat may bifalle,
Þe whilk alle thyng contenes of dignyté,
And in nathyng contende may be,
It contenes over-alle, on ilk party,
Bath bodily thyng and gastly,
And als helle es lawest place þat may falle,
Swa es þis heven alther-heghest place of alle;
And als sorow es ay in þe lawest place,
Swa es ay in þe heghest, ioy and solace.
And als tylle þe lawest place, drawes us syn,
Swa tylle þe heghest may vertues us wyn.
Þis heven es cald heven empiry
Þat es at say heven þat es fyry,
Ffor it semes alle als fyre of gret myght,
Þat brynnes noght bot schynes bryght.
Þis heven falles noght obout to ga,
Ne moves noght als dose þe other twa,
Bot standes ay stylle, for it es þe best,
And þe most worthi place of pees and rest
Þat God has ordaynd for þair wonyng,
Þat gyfes þam here tylle ryghtwise lyfyng.
Þis heven es cald Godes awen se,
Ffor þar syttes þe haly trinité,
And alle þe orders of aungels,
And alle þe blyssfulle spirites þat in heven dwels,
And þe saules of gud men and clene,
Þat in þis world ryghtwyse has bene.
And at þe dredfulle day of dome,
When alle men salle bifor God come,
Þan salle alle the ryghtwyse men wend þider,
In body and saule both togyder,
Þe whilk anely þan salle be save,
And fulle blys in body and saule have.
Þan salle mare ioy be in heven,
Þan hert may thynk or tong kan neven,
Or ere may here or any eghe se,
Þe whilk þai salle have, þat save salle be;
Þan passes þat ioy alle mens witt,
Als es fonden wryten in haly wrytt.

L.HI1: auris audivit, nec in cor ho|

LG.L: "Eghe moght never se, ne ere here,
Ne in-tylle mans hert com þe ioyes sere
Þat God has ordaynd þare and dyght,
Tylle alle þat here lufes him ryght."
Ffor swa mykelle ioy þare salle be,
Þat alle þe men of Cristianté,
If ilk ane war parfyte in clergy
In divinité and in astronomy,
In gemettry and gramer, and arte,
Couth noght gese bi þe thowsand parte,
Ne think in hert ne with tong neven,
Þe ioyes þat þan salle be in heven.
Ffor swa wyse here was never man yhit,
Ne swa sleghe, ne swa sotelle of wytt,
Had he never swa mykelle understandyng,
Bot God anely þat knawes alle thyng,
Þat couth telle a poynt or ymagyn
Of þe ioyes in heven þat never salle blyn,
Als proprely als þai er þare to say,
Bot als þe boke þam schewes, swa we may.
Alle manere of ioyes er in þat stede.
Þare es ay lyfe with-outen dede;
Þare es yhowthe ay with-outen elde,
Þare es alkyn welth ay to welde.
Þare es rest ay, with-outen travayle;
Þare es alle gudes þat never sal fayle;
Þare es pese ay, with-outen stryfe;
Þare es alle manere of lykyng of lyfe;
Þare es, with-outen myrknes, lyght;
Þare es ay day and never nyght;
Þare es ay somer fulle bryght to se,
And never mare wynter in þat contré:
Þare es alkyn druryes and rychesce,
And mare nobillay þan any man may gesce;
Þare es mare worsche[pe] and honoure,
Þan ever had kyng here or emparoure;
Þare es alkyn power and myght
And endeles wonyng sykerly dyght;
Þare es alkyn delyces and cese,
And syker peysilbilnespeysibilnes? and pese;
Þare es peysebelle ioy ay lastand,
And ioyfulle selynes ay lykand;
Þare es sely endeles beyng,
And endeles blysfulhede in alle thyng;
Þare es ay blysfulle certaynté,
And certayne dwellyng ay fre;
Þare es laykyng and myrthes sere;
Þare es laghyng and lufly chere;
Þare es melody and aungels sang;
And lovyng and thankyng ay omang;
Þare es alle frendschepe þat may be,
And parfyte luf and charyté;
Þare es acorde ay and anehede,
And yheldyng of mede for ilk gud dede;
Þare es lowtyng and reverence,
And boghsomnes and obedience;
Þare es alle vertuse with-outen vyce,
Þare es plenté of dayntes and delice;
Þare es alle þat lykes and may avayle,
And nathyng þat greves or may fayle;
Þare es alle þat gud es at wille,
And na thyng þat may be ille.
Þare es alle wisdom with-outen foly,
And honesté with-outen vilany;
Þare es bryghtnes and bewté
Of alle thing þat men salle þare se.
Alle þir ioyes er þare generalle,
Bot þe mast soverayne ioy of alle
Es þe syght of Godes bryght face,
Þat passes alle other ioyes and solace;
Ffor swa mykelle may na ioy be,
Als es þe syght of þe trinité,
Þat es þe Fader, and Son, and Haly gaste.
Þe syght of whilk salle be ioy maste;
Ffor-whi swa mykelle ioy and blys
Na ioy may be als es þis.Forwhi þar may be ioy ne blis, Swa mekyl to fele als is þis. (MS. Harl. 2394.)
Ffor alle þat þan salle se him ryght,
May knaw alle thing thurgh þat syght,
Þat ever was, and es, and salle be,
Als men may afterward rede and se.
Here have I shewed on a general manere
Þe ioyes of heven, many and sere.
Bot now will I specialy shew yhow mare
Of seven maners of blysses þare,
And of seven schenschepes in helle alle-swa,
Þat er even contrary tylle þa,
And whilk blysses falles specyaly
Tylle þe saule, and whilk tylle þe body,
Of þas þat God in heven salle se;
And whilk schendschepes salle appropried be
Tylle þe bodyse of þase, þat salle ga
Tylle helle, and whilk tille þe saules alle-swa.
I spak bifore of sere ioyes generaly,
Bot now will I here sere blysses specify,
And þair contraryes þat er hard,
Als yhe salle here be red afterward.
Saint Anselme says, þe haly man,
Als I here schew yhow kan,
Þat omang alle þe ioyes of heven,
Salle be sene specialle blysses seven,
Þat þe bodyse salle have þat salle be save,
And other seven þat þe saules salle have
In þe kyngdome of heven alle to-gyder,
After þe dome, when þai com þider;
Bot tylle þe synfulle bodyse þare ogayne
Þat salle be dampned tylle helle payne,
Seven specialle schendschepes salle falle
And other seven tylle þe saules with-alle
In helle to-gyder lastand ever-mare,
Wa es þam þat salle dwelle þare.
Heres now, ar I pass ferrer,
Whilk þa specyalle blysses er,
Þat er appropried tylle þa bodyse
And tylle þe saules of men ryghtwyse,
And þair contraryes, þat I schendschepes calle
Þat tylle þe synfulle bodyse and saules salle falle.
Þe fyrst blys es bryghtnes cald
Þat þe saved bodyse salle ay hald;
Ffor be þair bodyse never swa dym here,
In heven þai salle be fayre and clere
And mare schyneand and mare bryght,
Þan ever þe son was tylle mans syght;
Swa fayre a syght bifore was never sene,
Als salle be þan, ne swa clene,
When ilka body þat salle be save,
Swa mykelle bryghtnes þare salle have;
Ffor if a man had eghen swa bryght,
And if swa moght be, swa mykelle syght,
Als had alle þe creatures lyfand,
Yhit moght he noght, als I understand,
Ogayne swa mykelle bryghtnes loke,
Als a body salle have, þus says þe boke.
Bot þe dampned bodyse þare ogayne
Salle be foule and stynkand als carayne;
And fulle myrk and dym salle þai be
And fulle hydus and wlatsom to se;
Ffor swa foul a syght saw never man
Als þe dampned bodyse salle be þan,
Þat with þe saules salle dwelle in helledepe,
Þis salle to þam be payne and schendschepe.
Þe secunde blys after es swyftnes,
Þat ilk body salle have þat ryghtwise es;
Ffor in les while þan a man may wynke,
Þai salle mow fleghe whider þai wille thynke
With body and saule togyder thurgh flyght,
Ffra heven tylle erth and ogayne ryght,
And fra þe ta syde of þe world wyde,
If þai wyld, tylle þe tother syde;
And whider-swa þai þair thoght wille sett
Nathyng þam salle ogayne-stand ne lett.
Þis may þai do with-outen travayle,
And þis swyftnes salle never fayle;
Ffor als þe lyght of þe son, thurgh strenthe,
May fleghe fra þe est tylle þe west on lenthe,
Ryght swa þai may whyder þai wille, fleghe
In a schort twynkellyng of ane eghe.
Ffor þai salle be als swift þan
Als any thoght es here of man.
Bot þe synfulle bodyse salle ever-mare
On a contrary manere fare;
Þai salle be swa hevy charged with syn,
Both with-outen and with-in,
Þat þai salle have no myght to stand,
Ne unnethes to styr fote ne hand,
Ne yhit nane other lym of body,
Þair syn salle weghe on þam swa hevy.
Þe thred blys es strenthe and myght
Þat þe ryghtwise bodyse salle have thurgh ryght,
Ffor thof þai feble here and wayke ware,
Swa mykelle myght þai salle have þare,
And swa mykelle strenthe ay lastand,
Þat na thyng salle mow ogayne þam stand;
Swa þat þai salle mow remowe at þair wille,
Ilka mountayne and ilka hille,
Þat ever was in þe world sene;
And if þai wild, alle þe erth bidene,
With-outen any ogayne-standyng,
Or any lettyng of any-thyng;
And in þat dede have no mare swynk,
Þan a man has here to loke or wynk.
Bot þe synfulle bodyse, þat dampned salle be,
Salle be swa wayke and swa feble to se,
Þat þai salle unnethes mow stand,
Ne myght have anes to lyft þair hand
To wype þe teres fra þair eghen oway,
And þat waykenes salle last with þam ay.
Þe ferth blys alle-swa es fredome
Þat þe saved bodyse salle have þat salle come
Tylle heven, whare alkyn ioyes er,
To do what þai wille with-outen daunger;
Ffor-whi þai salle never fele na thyng
Bot þat at salle be at þair lykyng;
And na thing salle þam warn ne lett,
To do þair wille whare-swa it es sett;
Ffor alle thing tylle þam salle be boghand,
And na thing salle ogayne þam stand,
Ne ogayns þam na thing be sett,
Þair wille ne þair purpose to lett,
Nowther men, ne stele, ne stane, ne tre,
Ne noght elles, swa fre salle þai be;
Þai salle mow passe ay whare þai wille
And alle þair lykyng þan ful-fylle.
Þis fredom and þis fraunches
Salle be appropried tylle þe saved bodyse
With þe saules of þam þat God salle chese,
And þis fredom þai salle never lese.
Bot on contrary manere ogayne þat blys,
Þe dampned bodyse salle fredom mys;
Ffor þai salle be stresced in helle als thralle,
And alle þat may greve thole with-alle;
Þai salle be chaced ogayne þair wille
Tylle alle manere of thing þat es ille;
Þus salle þai in helle in thraldom be,
Ffra whilk þai may never mare fle.
Þe fyft blys, als clerkes wate wele,
Es hele þat þe saved bodyse salle fele,
With-outen seknes or grevaunce,
Or angre, or payne, or penaunce;
Ffor Ivel ne payne salle never þam greve,
Bot in hele and lykyng þai salle ay leve,
In heven with ioy on ilka syde,
Ffor þare salle þai be glorifyde.
Bot þe dampned bodyse, on other-wyse,
Salle have strang yvels and angwyse,
Als saules has þat in purgatory dwels
Ffor certayne tyme, als þe boke tels.
Bot swa lang lastes no sekenes þare.
Als in helle, for þat lastes ever-mare;
Ffor purgatory, als wryten es,
Has ende, and helle es endeles.
Þe sext blys es þe gret delyte,
Þat þe saved bodyse salle have swa parfyte
Þat no man lyfand kan ne may,
Swa mykelle yhern here, nyght ne day;
Ffor here moght never man far swa wele,
With swa mykelle delyte als þai salle fele
In alle þair wittes, ne swa mykelle ioy have,
Als God on þam salle þan vouche save.
Þai salle have swa mykelle ioy þare,
Þat nane of þam salle desyre mare;
Ffor als þe iren þat es glowand,
Thurgh strenthe and hete brynand,
Semes better to be fyre-bryght,
Þan iren, als tylle any mans syght,
Right swa þa þat in heven salle won
Salle seme bryghter þan fyre, and schyne als son
And be fulle-fyld ay in þat place
Of þe luf of God and of his grace,
And of alle delyces and ioy and blys,
Þe whilk þai salle never-mare mys;
And als men here oft has sene
Þat a vesselle dypped alle bidene
In water, or in other lycour thyn,
Be þe vesselle never swa wyde wyth-in,
Has water bath with-in and with-out,
Binethen, oboven, and alle about,
And na mare water with-in may hald,
Ne nane other thing þat lycoure es cald,
Right swa þe ryghtwise salle have ioy, mare
Þan þai may think or yhern þare;
Bot þe dampned bodyse ogayn-ward
Salle in helle fele payns strang and hard;
Ffor þai salle bryn in fyre, ilk ane,
Þat salle be menged with bronstane
Ffulle hate brynand, and with pyk,
And with other thing þat es wyk,
Omang vermyn þat salle þam byte,
And devels þat ay salle þam smyte,
With other payns strang and felle,
Ma þan hert may thynk or tong telle.
Þe sevend blys es endeles lyfe,
Þat þe saved salle have, with-outen stryfe,
Ever-mare in heven swa heghe;
Ffor þai salle ay lyf and never deghe,
And with God alle-myghty þare ay won,
Þat es sothfast Fader, and sothfast Son,
And þe Haly Gast in Trinité;
And in þat lyfe his face þai salle ay se.
Now if a man moght lyf here,
In þis world a thowsand yhere,
Yhit suld his lyfe be broght tylle ende,
And fra þis world bihoved him wende.
Yhit suld him thynk, and he toke kepe,
His lyfe noght bot als a dreme in slepe,
Þan suld þe lenthe of alle his lyfedays,
Seme bot als a day, als þe prophet says:

L.HI1: Quoniam mille anni ante oculos tuos, tanquum

LG.L: He says þus: "Lord! a thowsand yhere
Bi-for þine eghen, þat alle thyng sese here,
At þe last, es noght bot als yhister-day,
Þat was awhile and es passed oway."
Þus when þis lyfe tylle ende es broght,
Alle þe tyme of it semes als noght;
Þan es a day mare in heven swa clere,
Þan here er many thowsand yhere;
And many thowsand yheres here es les,
Þan þare a day, als þe boke bers witnes.
Þan salle þe lyf be als lang þare,
Als þat day lastes, and þat es ever-mare;
Ffor þare es ay day and never nyght,
Þarfor þe prophet says þus ryght:

L.HI1: Melior est dies una in atriis

LG.L: He says: "Loverd! better es a day lastand
In þi halles þan a thowsand;"
Þat es, better es in heven a day,
Þan a thowsand here þat passes oway;
Ffor alle þe days þat here may falle,
Passes oway, and þis lyf with-alle,
And in a day in heven salle be contende
Þe tyme þat never salle have ende;
Þan salle þat day, als þe boke us leres,
Pass many hundreth thowsand yheres.
And als in helle salle be nyght,
Als day salle be in heven bryght;
Ffor als men in heven salle ay day se,
Ryght swa salle nyght ay in helle be.
Þus salle day in heven be contende,
And nyght in helle, with-outen ende;
Bot se we noght how schort a day es here
To regard of a hundreth yhere?
Yhit es a hundreth yhere les
To regard of þe tyme þat es endeles;
Ffor Saint Austyn telles in a sarmon,
Þat a day here may be a porcyon,
Of ane hundreth yhere, als men may se,
Alle-if þat porcyon fulle lytylle be,
Bot þe space of ane hundreth yhere es
Na porcyon of endelesnes;
Ffor if a thowsand yhere þat es mare
Of endlesnes a porcyon ware,
After a thowsand thowsand yheres to kast,
Endlesnes suld sese þan at þe last,
And þat wille noght þe reson of endelesnes
Suffer þat it be schorter þan it es;
Ffor if endlesnes any end moght hald,
Þan war it endlesnes unproperly cald.
Bot in þat endlesnes es contende
Alle þe tyme þat may have nane ende;
And lyfe in heven salle als lang be
Als men salle tyme þare with-outen ende se,
Þan semes it wele, als I sayd are,
Þat lyfe salle be þare ever-mare
Wharfor ilk man with hert stedfast,
Suld seke þat lyfe þat ay salle last,
Þe whilk ilk man may lyghtly wyn,
Þat here lyfes wele and wille fle syn,
And leve noght þat lyf þat lastes ay
Ffor þis lyfe here þat passes oway;
Ffor þat lyfe es syker, and swa es noght þis.
Þat lyfe es swa fulle of ioy and blys
Þat a man salle thynk þare a hundreth yhere,
In þat lyfe, schorter þan a day here.
Tylle þat ioyfulle lyf may alle men com
Þat meke of hert er here, and bowsom.
Þus salle endles lyfe appropryed be,
Tylle þe saved bodyse þat ay God salle se.
Bot þe dampned þat tylle helle salle wende,
Salle have ded þare with-outen ende,
And þat ded salle ay new þam gryefe.
In þat ded þai salle ay lyefe,
And swa be pyned, in þair wyttes fyve,
Þat þair lyfe salle seme mare ded þan lyve.
Þai salle seme, whether þai lyg or stand,
Als men in transyng, ay deghand;
Þai salle ay deghand lyf, and lyfand dyghe,
And ever-mare payns of ded þus dryghe,
And þare-with be tourmented, ay omang,
With other bytter payns and strang;
Þar-for þe lyfe in helle may be cald
Þe secund ded, and swa may we it hald.
Þan may þai say, þat salle lyf þare,
Allas! þat ever moder þam bare.
Here have I tald, als yhe moght here,
Of seven manere of blysses sere,
Þat þe saved bodyse salle have thurgh ryght
With þe saules in heven bryght,
And of þe seven schendschepes alle-swa
Þat es even contrary tylle þa,
Þe whilk þe bodyse in helle salle have ay,
Þat salle be dampned at domesday.
Bot I wille schew yhow yhit with-alle,
Seven manere of blysses, þat salle falle
Tylle þe saules namely with þe bodyse,
Of alle þe men þat er gude and ryghtwise,
Þat salle be saved at þat tyde,
And in heven be gloryfyde;
And yhit seven schendschepes wille Ineven,
Þat er even contrary tylle þa seven,
Þe whilk salle falle, with-outen ende,
Tylle þa saules of þe synfulle þat salle wende,
With þe bodyse, untylle helle pytt,
Als es fonden in haly wrytt.
Þe fyrst blys þat þe saules salle have
Of ryghtwise men, þat salle be save
Es wisdom; for þai salle knaw and se
Alle þat was, and es, and yhit salle be.
Þai salle have knawyng of God fully,
And of þe myght of þe Fader alle-myghty,
Þai salle knaw þe wytt of þe son and taste,
And þe gudenes of þe Haly-gaste:
Þus salle þair knawyng parfyte be,
In alle þe haly trinité.
Þai salle knaw alle thing and wytt,
Þat God has done and salle do yhit,
In heven, in helle and in erth aywhare,
Þus wise þai salle be ever-mare.
Ffor þai salle have swa mykelle grace,
When þai se God, face to face,
Þat nathyng, þat God ever dyd,
Salle be layned fra þam ne hyd,
Þat es to say, of þat God vouches save,
Þat any creature knawyng may have;
Ffor Saint Austyn þat mykelle couth of clergy,
Says in a sarmon þat he made openly,
Þat, in þe syght of God þat þai salle se,
Thre manere of knawyng tylle þam salle be.
Ffor þai salle se him þare both God and man,
And þam-self þai salle se in him þan,
And alle men and alle thing, les and mare.
Þai salle se, and knaw in þat syght þare,
Als we may thre thynges se here
In a myroure of glas, þat es clere;
Ane es þe myrour þat byfor us es,
Ane other es our awene face and lyknes,
And þe thred we may þar-in se yhit,
Þat es alle thyng þat es onence it;
Right swa men salle se God als he es,
In þe myroure of his bryghtnes,
Als properly als possible may be,
Tylle any creature him to se.
Þai salle se þam-self in him so bryght,
And alle men to-gyder, at a syght,
And alle other thyng þai salle knawe,
And se over-alle, both hegh and lawe.
Alle men þan salle se þat þare salle dwelle,
Alle þe creatures in heven and helle.
Þare salle be schewed þan tylle þam, apertly,
Sere privetese of God alle-myghty,
Þat na man here moght knaw ne wytt
Thurgh clergy, ne thurgh haly-wrytt;
Þat es, how God invysible es,
And unchaungeable, and endles;
And how he was bifor alle thing,
And with-outen any bygynnyng;
And how, and whi, he salle be
With-outen ende, þai salle þan se;
Alle thyng þat now es fra þam hyd,
Salle þan tylle þam be knawen and kyd.
Þai salle þan se þare, openly,
Of alle thynges þe skylle and þe cause whi;
Als whi ane es chosen here and taken,
And ane other left and forsaken;
Whi ane es uptane tylle a kyngdom,
And ane other es putted in-tylle thraldom;
And whi som childer er ded and lorn
In þair moder wambe, ar þai be born;
Þai salle knaw, with-outen drede,
Skylle whi som deghes in þair barnhede,
And som after when þai mast strenthe weld;
And whi som lyfes tylle þair mast eld;
Þai salle yhit sertaine skylle se þan
Whi som er born in fayre schap of man,
And som in uncomly stature,
And whi som er ryche here, and som pore,
And whi som childer geten in hordom,
Er baptized, and has cristendom,
And som þat er in lele wedlayk born,
Ar þai be cristened, er ded and lorn;
And whi som bi[g]ynnes to be stedfast
To lyfe wele, and endes ille at þe last;
And whi som has here ille bigynnyng,
And, at þe last, mase a gud endyng.
Of þir thynges, and of other many,
Þe skylles salle be knawen þan openly,
In þe boke of lyfe þat open salle be,
Þe whilk es þe syght of þe trinité.
Þus salle alle men, þat in heven þan dwelles,
Knaw and witt, als Saint Austyn telles,
And in þe bryghtnes of God openly se
Alle thing þat ever was, or yhit salle be,
And alle þe soth of ilk thyng, and skylle,
Als fer-forth als God vouches safe, and wille.
Þare salle ilk man als wele knaw other,
Als a man here knawes hys syster or brother,
And wyt of what contré þai ware,
And wha þam gatt, and wha þam bare.
Ilk ane salle knaw þan other thoght
And alle þe dedes þat þai ever wroght;
Þus wyse salle þai be þat salle come
Tylle þe kyngdom of heven, after þe dome.
Þai salle be Godes sons, and tille him lyke,
And be made his heyres of hevenryke,
And be alle als Godes of gret myght,
Als þe prophet, in þe psauter, says ryght:
He says: "I sayd, 'yhe er Godes alle
And Godes sons men salle yhow calle'."
Wharfor it semes, þat when þai com
Tylle heven, þai salle be fulle of wysdom
And fulle of myght, lastand ever-mare,
When þai salle alle be als Godes þare.
Bot now may þou ask me and lere
A questyon, and say on þis manere:
'Salle þai oght think þat salle be safe,
On þe syns of whilk þai þam schrafe
Here in þair lyfe, and made þam clene,
And of þam assoyled has bene?'
Saint Anselme answers to þis,
And says þat þou þat salle have heven blys,
Salle love God and thank him þare
Of alle gudes, both les and mare,
Þat he has done tylle þe here,
And tylle alle other, on þe same manere,
Þe whilk, at þe day of dome, salle be safe,
And with þe endles blys salle have.
Gret gud he dose þe, whils þou lyfes,
When he þi syns þe here forgyves;
How moght þou þan, with hert fre,
Thank God of þat þat he has forgyven þe,
Alle þe syns þat þou has wroght,
If þou moght thynk on nane in thoght?
Bot þou salle þis understand wele,
Þat na mare grevance salle þou fele,
Ne na mare payne have, ne myslykyng,
When þou has of þi syns meneyng,
Þan he has, þat som tyme had in stryfe
A sare wound, with swerd or knyfe,
Þat parfytely es haled and wele,
Of whilk he may na mare sareThe MS. has 'sale'. fele;
And als þou now has na schame of þe dede
Þat þou dyd in þi barnhede,
Or þat þou dyd in þi dronkennes,
Of whilk tylle þe now na schame es.
Na mare schame salle þou þan have in thoght,
Of þe syns þat þou here has wroght,
Of whilk þou ert here schryven parfytely,
And þat God has forgyfen here, thurgh mercy
And na mare þan Petre now has schame
Of þat, þat he forsoke our Lord bi name;
Or Mary Maudelayne now has of hir syn
Þat scho som tyme delyted hir in.
Na mare schame salle men þan have
Of þair syn here done, þat salle be save.
Bot for-þi þat God þat boght us fre,
Wyld thurgh his mercy and his peté,
And couth, thurgh his awen wytt clere,
And myght wele, thurgh his awen powere,
Swa gret syns þam frely forgyve
And þe woundes haleThe MS. has 'have'., þat war gryfe,
Whare-thurgh þai had deserved wele
Þe pyne of helle ever-mare to fele,
Þarfor þai salle luf him þe mare,
And þe mare him love and thank þare,
And als wele for other mens trispas
And other mens syn þat he heled has,
Als for þair awen þat þai wroght here,
Þarfor says David, on þis manere:
He says: "I salle þe mercyes syng
Of our Loverd, ay with-outen cesyng."
And swa salle alle syng, with-outen ende,
Þat tylle þe blys of heven salle wende;
And swa moght þai on nane wise syng,
Warn þai had of þair syns meneyng,
Þat þai had done here bodily
And God forgaf thurgh his mercy;
Þus salle þe saule be fulle of wysdom þare,
And alle thing knaw and se, als I sayd are.
Bot þe saules þat with þe bodyse salle synk
In-tylle helle, salle on na gud thynk,
Ne have witt, ne knaw, ne fele
Na dede þat ever was done wele,
Bot on þair payns salle be alle þair thoght
And on þair syns þat þai had wroght;
Ffor þai salle on nathyng have meneyng,
Bot anely on þair awen wicked lyfyng,
And on þair sorow, with-outen ende,
And on þair wrechednes þat salle þam schende
Þe whilk þai salle, ay, bifor þam se,
And þat syght tylle þam schendschepe sallebe.
Þe secund blys þat þe saule salle fele,
With þe bodyse, als þir clerkes wate wele,
Salle be frendschepe and parfyte love,
Þat es mare þan ever man moght here prove;
Ffor ilk ane salle mare luf other þan,
Þan ever lufed here any man,
And als parfytely and als lang
Als he salle luf him-self omang.
And þat luf salle be fested swa fast,
Þat it salle never fayle, bot ay last;
Ffor als ilka lym of a body
Lufes alle þe other lyms kyndely,
And yhernes, ay, gretly þair hele,
Swa parfyte þat luf salle be and lele;
Ffor þai salle alle be of ane assent
And of a wille and of ane entent;
Ffor þai salle be þan alle als a body
In sere lyms, and als a saule anely;
And God þair heved salle be þare,
Þat salle þam luf als mykelle or mare,
Als dose þe heved of þe body þat loves
Þe lyms kyndely þat on it moves.
Þat clere luf and þat alliance
Salle never-mare fayle, thurgh na distance,
Ne thurgh stryfe, þat man may make;
Þat band of luff salle never slake.
Bot even þe contrary salle men se,
Omang þe saules þat dampned salle be;
Ffor þai salle be fulle of felony,
Of hatred, of wreth and of envy;
Swa þat ilk ane wald with other fyght,
And strangelle other, if þai myght.
Þus salle þai hate and stryfe ilk ane,
Ffor peese salle be omang þam nane,
Ne rest, ne eese, ne worschepe,
Bot travayle, and pyne, and schendschepe.
Bot God alle-myghty, and alle-swa alle his
Þat with him salle dwelle in heven blis,
Salle þam in sorow and pyne se
And of þam þai salle have na peté,
Bot hate þam als Godes enmyse.
And þat hatredyn salle þan be ryghtwyse;
Ffor þe fader, þat þan salle be save,
Na peté of þe son þare salle have,
Þat salle be dampned tylle helle payne;
Ne þe son, þat salle be saved þare ogayne,
Salle have na reuthe, ne na pyté,
Of þe fader þat dampned salle be;
Ne þe moder, on þe same manere,
Of þe doghter þat scho lufed here;
Ne þe doghter of þe moder na mare;
Ne þe brother of þe syster þare;
Ne þe syster of þe brother.
Nane of þam salle have reuthe of other;
Ne nane other, þat salle be saved þan,
Salle have reuthe ne peté of dampned man.
Bot when þe ryghtwyse þe synfulle salle se
Pyned in helle, glad þai salle be,
Ffor twa skyls, and ioyfulle and fayne;
Ane es, for-þi þat þai er skaped þat payne,
Ane other es for-þi þat Godes vengeance
Es ryghtwise, and his ordinance.
Þis proves þe prophete, als þe boke schewes us,
Þare he says in þe psauter þus:
He says þat "ilka ryghtwyse man
Fulle glad and blyth salle be þan,
When þai Godes vengeance se
On þe synfulle, þat þan dampned salle be.
Þe thred blys, als men may in boke rede,
Es veray acord and anehede,
Þat þe saules salle have in heven to-gyder,
With þe bodyse, when þai com þider;
Ffor ilk ane salle folow others wille,
And ilk ane othe[r]s lykyng fullfylle;
And als þine ane eghe folows ryght.
Þe tother, þare it settes þe syght,
And nouther may turne, hyder ne þider,
Bot þai both ay turne to-gyder,
Right swa salle God acord with alle his,
And ilk ane with other in that blys;
And to what thyng þe saule has talent,
To þat þe body salle, ay, assent;
And what-swa God þan wille be done
To þat þai salle assent alle-sone;
And what thyng swa þai þan wille,
Þat salle God als-tyte fulle-fylle.
Þis acorde and anehede sall never ceese,
Bot ever-mare last with rest and peese.
Alle salle þai be alle ane in company,
And als a saule and a body.
Bot þe dampned þare ogayne salle stryve,
Ilkane with other, for þair wicked lyve;
Ffor ilk ane salle hate other þan,
And ilk ane salle wery other and ban;
Ilk ane salle yherne with other to fyght,
And ilk ane wald sla other if þai myght;
Þe body salle hate þe saule bi skylle,
Ffor þe saule here thoght ay þe ille;
Þe saule salle ay hate þe body,
Ffor þe body wroght þe foly;
And for-þi þat þe saule fyrst syn thoght
And þe body it afterward wroght,
And wyld noght leve, ne stand þare ogayne,
Untylle þe ded þe body had slayne.
Þar-fore bath to-gyder salle dwelle,
With-outen ende, in þe pyne of helle.
Þe ferth blys, omang þe tother alle,
Þat to þe saules, with þe bodyse, salle falle,
Þe whilk salle be saved, es powere;
Ffor þai salle þare have both fer and nere,
Swa mykelle power and maistry
And lordschip, and be swa myghty
Þat alle thyng þan salle be done
At þair wille, hastily and sone;
And what-swa þai wille think in thoght,
Alle salle be at þair wille þare wroght;
Ffor alle thing salle be tylle [þam] boghand,
And nathyng salle ogayne þam stand;
Ffor God salle fulle-fylle alle þair lykyng,
And folow þair wille in alle thing.
Þus salle þai haf þare gret powere,
And heghnes, for þair awen gret lawnes here,
Þat þai had in þair lyfe days,
And þarfor God, in þe gosspelle says:
He says: "Wha-swa here lawes him ryght
He salle be heghed, in heven bryght."
Bot þe dampned þare ogayne halely,
Salle want alkyn power and maistry,
And þare-with þai salle tharne alle thing,
Of whilk men moght have lykyng.
Þai salle ay be in gret dred and awe,
And under fote ay be halden lawe.
Þai salle have nathyng at þair wille,
Bot alle thing þat salle lyke þam ille.
Mykelle sorow þam salle þan bityde,
Ffor þair heghenes here, and þair pryde,
Als þe bok says þat beres wytnes,
And als in þe same gosspelle wryten es:
Þat es, "wha-swa heghe here wille him bere
He salle be lawed" and putted in daungere,
Þat es in gret daunger of fendes,
In pyne of helle, þat never endes.
Þe fyft blys þat salle falle alswa,
To þe saules, þat with þe bodyse salle ga
Tylleheven-ryke, es honoure and worschepe,
Of whilk God him-self salle tak kepe;
Ffor þai salle have þare sere honours,
And be corouned, als kynges and emparours.
And sytt in setyls schynand bryght,
With alkyn nobelay, rychely dyght;
With bryghtnes of lyght þai salle be cled,
And gret reverence þam salle be bed,
And be honourd als Godes frendes dere,
Ffor þe worschepe þat þai dyd him here,
In gud werkes, þat tylle him war swete,
Þarfor þus says David, þe prophete:
"Þi frendes, Loverd, þat honourd þe
Es mykelle honourd, and swa ay salle be."
Bot þe dampned, þat with syn er fyled,
Þare ogayne salle be revyled,
And despysed, and ay schent with-alle,
And stresced ogayne þair wille als thralle,
And pyned with gretter paynes sere,
Þan ever was sene in þis world here;
Þai salle[thole] alle thyng þat schendschepe es
With payn and sorow þat es endles,
Omang hete and cald, vermyn and stynk,
And alkyn fylth þat hert may think;
And alle þe sorow þai þat salle fele,
Salle be endles, als þai salle knaw wele.
Þe sext blys þat to the saules of ryghtwise
Salle be appropryed þan with þe bodyse,
In þe kyngdom of heven, es sykernes,
To dwelle ay þare whare alkyn ioy es,
