Ffor þai salle be þare syker and certayne
To have endeles ioy, and never-mare payne,
And to won ay þare, with-outen dout,
And with-outen lettyng, and putting out,
And with-outen alle manere of drede;
Ffor of nathyng þare þai salle have nede,
Þai salle noght far, als men fares here
Þat lyfes ay in dred and were;
Ffor here, both kyng and emparoure
Has dred to tyne þair honoure;
And ilka ryche man has dred alle-swa
His gudes and ryches to for-ga;
And ilk man, þat here fares wele,
Has ay dred angers to fele.
Bot þai þat salle com tylle heven blys,
Salle never have dred þat ioy to mys;
Ffor þai salle be syker Inoghe þare,
Þat þair ioy salle last ever-mare.
Bot þe dampned men þare ogayne,
Salle ay be dredand in þair payne,
Þat þair payns suld eked be,
And be made mare grevous to se,
Ffor þe devels sal, ay, on þam gang
To and fra, over-thewrt and endlang;
And omang þam ay ymagyne,
How þai may eke þair sorow and pyne;
And þe mare payne þat þai tille synfulle salle seke
Þe mare þai þair awen payne salle eke.
And, if þai do swa, it es na ferly,
Ffor þai er ay fulle of Ire and envy.
Þe devels salle ay opon þam gang,
And ay on þam stamp with þair feth omang
And threst þam doune, in fyre and smoke,
And þarfor says Iob þus in a boke:
He says, "grysely devels salle gang and com
On þe synfulle þat tylle God war unbowsom."
Þus dredand salle þai ay be þare,
Þat þair payne suld be ay mare and mare;
Ffor þai salle be certayne þare þai dwelle,
Þat þai salle never com out of helle.
Þe sevend blys es ioy parfyte,
Þat þe saules salle have, with gret delyte,
With þe bodyse þat saved salle be,
And won in heven, whare þai salle ay God se
Ffor-whi ilk ane þare salle þat tyde,
In body and saule be gloryfyde,
And fulle ioy and blys have with-alle,
With alle manere of delyces þat may falle.
Ilk ane with other salle be knawen,
And fele other mens ioy als þair awen;
And mare ioy and blys moght never be,
Þan ilk ane salle þare-on other se.
Þai salle se, in heven-ryke swa wyde,
Many sere ioyes, on ilka syde;
Ffor þare salle be mare sere ioyes þan,
Þan ever couth noumbre erthly man;
Of whilk syght þai salle mare ioy have,
Þan any man moght yhern or crave.
Ilk ane salle be payed swa wele
Of his part of ioy þat he salle fele,
Þe whilk he salle parfytely have þare,
Þat he salle willen yhern no mare;
Þare salle ilk ane many thowsandes se
In sere ioyes, als him-self salle be.
And þe syght of ilka ioy þan,
Salle be swa delytable tille ilka man,
Þat þe ioy of a syght þare salle pas
Alle þe ioyes þat ever in erth was;
And alle þat tylle heven salle be tane
Salle þare þan se þa ioyes ilk ane.
And þe syght of ilka ioy þare, salle be
Ioy tylle ilka man þat it salle se,
Þan salle ilk man have ma ioyes in heven,
Þan hert may thynk, or tong kan neven;
Þai salle have ioy, with-in and with-out,
Oboven, benethe, and alle obout.
Oboven þam, þai salle have ioyfully
Of þe syght of God alle-myghty,
Binethe þam, of þe sternes and planetes sere,
And þe world þat þan salle be bryght and clere;
Oboven þam, of heven þat þai bryght salle se,
And of other creatures þat fair salle be,
With-in þam, of þe glorifying of man,
Of þe body and saule to-gyder þan;
With-outen þam, of þe blysfulle companyse
Of aungels, and of men ryghtwise.
Þai salle have ioy in alle þair wittes,
In heven with God þare he syttes;
Ffirst þai salle se with þair eghen bryght
Many a fayre blyssfulle syght;
Þai salle þair God apertly se,
And alle þe thre parsons in trinité,
Þe Fader, and Son, and Haly-gaste,
Þat sight salle be þair ioy maste.
Ffor als he es, þai salle him se þan,
Sothfast God, and sothfast man;
Thurgh whilk syght þai salle knaw,
And se alle thing both heghe and law
And se alle þe werkes þat ever God wroght;
And ilk mans dede, and ilk mans thoght,
And alle þat salle in helle be þan,
Ilka develle and ilka man,
And alle payns þat salle be þare,
Þai salle se, both les and mare;
And alle erth, and þe hevens obout,
And alle þat es, with-in and with-out;
Alle salle þai se, thurgh myght and grace,
In þe bryghtnes of Godes face,
Of whilk þai salle ever-mare have syght,
Þat þe mast ioy es in heven bryght.
And for þai salle ay þus God bihald,
Þai salle knaw alle thyng, þat þai knaw wald.
In þis lyfe here men sese him noght,
Bot anely thurgh ryght trowth in thoght,
Als thurgh a myroure be lyknes,
Bot þare salle men se him als he es.
Here men him sese gastly, thurgh grace,
Bot þare salle men se him, face tylle face.
And þat syght þare salle alle men have,
With-outen ende, þat salle be save.
Þai salle alle-swa se þare, apertly,
His blysfulle Moder Saint Mary
Þat next syttes God in heven bryght,
Oboven alle aungels, als es ryght;
Ffor he chese hir tylle his moder dere,
And of hir toke flessch and blode here,
And vouched safe to souke hir brest,
Þarfor it es ryght scho sytt him nest.
Scho es swa fayre þare scho syttes,
Þat hir fayrnes passes all mens wittes;
A gret ioy þat may be cald,
Hir fairnes anely to behald.
Þai salle se þare, als þe boke telles,
Alle þe neghen orders of aungels,
Þat er swa fayre on to loke,
And swa bryght, als says þe boke,
Þat alle fayrnes of þis lyfe here,
Þat ever was sene, fer or nere,
Þat any man myght ordayne defautles,
War noght a poynt to þat fairnes,
Þat þai salle se þar of þat syght
Of þe ordres of þe aungels bryght.
Þai salle se þam fulle pleysand þan,
And servisabylle tylle God and man;
And ilk ane ordre, in þair degré
Salle do þat þat mast lykand salle be,
Bath tylle God and tylle man ryght;
A gret ioy salle be þare of þat syght,
Ffor ilk ane aungelle bi him-ane
Salle clerer schyne þan ever son schane;
Þat syght men may a gret ioy calle,
To se þe aungels swa bryght alle,
Þat in heven salle be sene to-gyder;
Þat syght salle alle se þat salle com þider.
Swa fayre a syght, als þat salle seme,
Couth never na wytt here ymagyn ne deme.
Þai salle se in heven alle-swa
Patriarches, and prophetes and other ma,
And apostels and evangelistes,
Þat folowd nane other lyf bot cristes.
Þai salle se Innocentes many ane,
Of whilk som was, in Goddes name slane,
And other martyrs and confessours,
And haly heremytes and doctours,
Þat haly wryt wald teche and ken;
And many other haly men,
Lered and lewed, þat lyfed wele here,
Both religiouse and seculere.
Þai salle se haly virgyns þare
Þat here lufed God, ay mare and mare,
And keped þam chast, for Godes sake,
Of whilk som wald þe ded for his luf take.
Þai salle se þare in ioy and blys,
Other þat God salle chese for his,
Als wedded men þat lyfed wele here,
And other many of states sere.
A fayr syght salle be þan to se,
Of alle þe fayr folk þat þare salle be,
Þat bryghter salle schyne þan ever schane son,
Þis syght salle alle se þat þare salle won.
Þai salle alle-swa apertly se
Ilk ane be worscheped in his degré,
With gret nobelay, and have sere honours,
And alle be als kynges and emparours,
Coround with ryche corouns of blys,
A fulle delytabelle syght salle be þis.
Þai salle se þare þe gret medes,
Þat men salle have þare, for þair gud dedes,
After ilk ane of þam has lyfed here;
And þas er swamykelle, and many, and sere,
Þat never ende salle þai have bot last ay,
Þat na man, thurgh wytt, mesure may,
Ne þam reken, ne telle þam kan,
Swa many medes þai salle have þan.
Þair medes salle be swa precyouse,
And swa delitable, and plenteuouse,
Þat na man lyfand, als þe boke says,
Couth ne myght þam gesce ne prays.
Bot þa medes salle lyke þam als wele,
Þat þam seese, als þam þat salle þam fele.
Þai salle se heven fulle large and wyde,
And round and even, on ilka syde,
And bryghter schynand þan ever schane son;
Wele salle þam be þat þare salle won.
A delitable syght þat salle be
Tylle þam þat salle dwelle in þat contré.
Þat contré swa fayre es on to loke,
And swa bryght and brade, als says þe boke,
Þat alle þis world, þare we won yhit
War noght bot als a myddyng-pytt
To regard of þat contré swa brade,
Þat God swa mykelle and fayr has made.
Þat contré es halden swa large a land,
Þat with-in þe space of þat myght stand
Many a thowsand of werldes sere,
Þof ilk world war als large als þis here;
And þat land es cald soveraynly
Þe kyngdom of God alle-myghty,
Þe whilk es made als a ceté,
Whare men salle many wonynge-stedes se,
Þare alle þe haly men salle dwelle,
Þarfor says Crist þus in þe gospelle:
He says "wonyng-stedes er many
In þe hows of my fader God alle-myghty."
Our Loverd, his fader hous calles
His kyngdom, þat tille alle his falles,
Þe whilk es as a cité bryght,
With alkyn ryches dubbed and dyght,
Als says Saint Iohan, Godes derlyng dere,
In þe apocalyps, on þis manere:

L.HI1: Vidi sanctam civitatem Ierusalem novam descendentem
de celo, paratam sicut sponsam viro suo ornatam.

LG.L: "I saw," he says, "þe haly ceté
Of Ierusalem, alle new to se,
Comand doun fra heven bryght,
Of God alle-myghty rychely dyght,
Als bryde, made fayre tylle hir brydegome;"
Þus says Saint Iohan he saw come.
Þis ceté es for to understand,
Haly kyrk þat here es fyghtand
Ogayne þe develle and his myght,
Þat it assayles, both day and nyght;
Bot þat fyght salle noght last ay,
It salle last no langer þan tylle domesday.
Þan salle haly kyrk, of fyghtyng cees,
And be with God, in rest and pees;
Ffor it es bryde, and God es brydegome;
Þan salle þai both to-gyder come,
And in heven won ay to-gyder;
And alle þair childer salle þan com þider.
Þat to þam has bene bowsom and trewe;
And þat bi-takens þe ceté newe;
Ffor þan salle haly kyrk þat tyde,
In heven be new gloryfyde,
And won ay þare with God alle-myghty,
In ioy, and myrthe, and melody.
Bot yhit haly kyrk, þat es Godes bryde,
Bihoves be fyghtand, yhit here to abyde
Þe comyng of Crist þat es hir brydegome,
Þat ay es myghty for to over-come,
Ffor haly kyrk fyghtes for Godes ryght;
And God overcomes thurgh his myght.
On twa-wise may haly kyrk be tane,
And, at þe last, salle bath be in ane;
On a manere es cald haly kyrk fyghtand,
On ane other es haly kyrk over-comand.
Þir clerkes says als þe boke beres witnes,
Þat haly kyrk, þat here fyghtand es,
Es noght els, bot a gaderyng
Of alle cristen men of lele lyfyng.
Haly kyrk over-comand es alle-swa
God with alle þe company of þa
Þat dwelles with him, in his blys,
Þe whilk he has hyght tylle alle his.
Under haly kyrk, þat here fyghtand es,
Er alle gud cristen men, mare and les.
Under haly kyrk þat es over-comand,
Er alle haly men in heven wonand.
Bot haly kyrk þat here fyghtes fast,
After þe day of dome at þe last,
In þe bryght ceté in heven salle won
Ever-mare, with hir spowse Godes Son;
Ffor þan salle þe noumbre fulle-fyld be
Of alle haly men in þat ceté,
Thurgh haly kyrk þat es Godes spowse;
And þat ceté Crist calles his Faders howse,
Ffor þare salle alle men þat er ryghtwise and haly,
Ever-mare dwelle in aungels company;
And ilk ane salle have a blysfulle wonyng,
And ioy parfyte, with-outen endyng.
Þis ceté of heven þat es wyde and brade,
Na man wate properly how it es made,
Ne can, thurgh wrytt, ymagyn in thoght,
Of whatkyn matere it es wroght,
It es noght made of lyme ne stane,
Ne of tre; for of swilk matere has it nane,
Als þir erthly cetese er made of here,
Þat er made of corruptybelle matere;
Ffor na thyng falles to be in þat ceté,
Þat corruptybelle or fayland may be.
Bot þe matere þare-of, als I trow,
Es of alle thing þat es of gret vertow.
Þis ceté was never made with hand,
Bot thurgh þe myght and witt of God alle-weldand
Þis ceté contenes alle heven-ryke
Bot nane wate properly to what it es lyke;
We fynd wryten, þat it es fayre and bryght,
Bot na man kan descryve it ryght;
Ffor swa wyse clerk was never of lyve,
Þat þe fairnes of it couth properly descryve,
Bot alle-if I kan noght descryve þat stede,
Yhit wille I ymagyn, on myne awen hede,
Ffor to gyf it a descripcion;
Ffor I have þare-to, gret affeccyon;
And gret comforth and solace it es to me
To thynk and spek of þat fayr ceté;
Þat travaille may greve me nathyng,
Ffor þare-in have I gret lykyng.
Ogayne ryght trowth nathing I do,
If I lyken þe ceté þat me langes to,
Þe whilk men may lyken on som party,
Bath to bodily thing and gastly.
And for-þi þat alle thing þat es clere and bryght
Es mast lykand here tylle bodily syght,
Þarfor I wille it lyken tille bodily thing.
Þat es fayre to syght with gastly understandyng.
Þe bryght ceté of heven es large and brade,
Of whilk may na comparyson be made
Tille na ceté þat on erth may stand,
Ffor it was never made with mans hand.
Bot yhit, als I ymagyn in my thoght,
I lyken it tylle a ceté þat war wroght
Of gold, of precyouse stanes sere,
Opon a moteMS. Lands. 348 reads 'mount'., sett of berylle clere,
With walles, and wardes, and turrettes,
And entré, and yhates, and garettes;
And alle þe walles war made, of þat ceté,
Of preceyouse stanes and ryche perré;
And alle þe turrettes, of cristalle schene,
And þe wardes enamyld, and overgylt clene,
And þe yhates of charbucles suld falle,
And þe garettes aboven of rubys and curalle;
And at þat ceté had lanes and stretes wyde,
And fayr bygyngs on ilka syde,
Alle schynand als gold bryght burnyst
And with alkyn ryches replenyst;
And þat alle þe stretes of þe ceté and þe lanes
War even paved with precyouse stanes;
And þat þe brede and lenthe of þat ceté
War mare þan here es of any cuntré;
And þat alle manere of melody
Of musyk and of mynstralsy,
Þat moght be schewed with mowthe or hand,
War continuely þare-in sownand,
And þat ilk day, on sere manere suld falle,
Swa þat na man moght irk with-alle.
And þat ilka lane and ilka strete,
Of þis ceté war fulle of savours swete,
Of spycery and of alle other thyng,
Of whilk any swete savoure moght spryng;
And þat þar war plenté of mete and drynk,
And of alle other delyces þat man may thynk;
And þat ilka citesayne þat wonned þare,
Had als mykelle bewté or mare,
Als Absolon, þat swa fayre was,
Whase bewté moght bi skylle pas
Þe bewté of alle manere of men erthly,
Swa clene he was in lym and body;
And þare-with als mykelle strenthe had omang
Als Sampson had, þat was so strang,
Þat a thowsand men armed clene
He over-come and felled doune alle bi-dene;
And þat ilkane war als swyft to pas
And to ryn, als Assahelle of fote was,
And swa swyft was to ryn and ga,
Þat thurgh rase wald turne bath buk and ra;
And þat ilkane had þare-with als mykelle lykyng
And als mykelle þair wille in alle thing,
Als Salamon had, þat als God vowched save
Þat had alle thyng þat he wald have:
And þat ilkane þar-with, had als mykelle fredome
Als August had þat was emparour of Rome,
Tylle whame alle landes of þe world obout
Served, and tille him war underlout;
And þat ilkane had with-alle als continuele hele
Als Moyses had þat was swa lele,
Þat God wald never with yvelle dere him,
Bot anely þat he made his eghen dym;
And þat þare-with, if possible ware,
Ilkane moght als lang be lyfand þare,
Als Matussale namely dyd here,
Þat lyfed nere a thowsand yhere;
And þat ilk ane moght als mykelle wisdom weld,
Als Salamon had, þat men swa wise held,
Þat thurgh his wisdom had knawyng
Of alle thing and understanding;
And þat ilk ane þare-with lufed als wele or mare,
And als gud frende ay tylle other ware,
Als David tylle Ionathas was kyd,
Wham he lufed als he his awen saule dyd;
And þat ilk ane with þat honourd ware
Of alle þe other þat wond þare,
Als Ioseph was of þe Egypciens ryght,
Wham þai lowted als loverd of gret myght;
And þare-with þat ilk ane war in alle thing
Als mykelle als was Alexander the gret kyng
Þat conquerd Affryk, Europe and Asy,
Þat contened alle þe world halely;
And þat ilkane acorded with other in anehede,
Als Lisyas with Sampson dyd in dede,
Of whilk nouther wald nathing do,
Bot als ayther of þam assented þare-to;
And with alle þis, þat ilkane als syker ware
Of þair dwellyng, to won lang þare,
Als Ennoc and Hely, on þe same wyse,
Þat er syker of þair dwellyng in paradyse,
Ffra þe tyme þat þai war þider ravyst,
And salle be untylle þe comyng of Anticrist;
And over alle þis, þat ilkane als mykelle joy had
Als he suld have þat war lad
Tylle þe galows, and sodainly in þe gate
War tane and putted tille a kynges state;
And, þare-with, þanþat? tylle ilk ane suld falle
Alle þe ioyes þai moght have alle.
He þat alle þes had, als bifore wryten es,
Suld pass alle þe world in worthines:
What man, thurgh witt, couth telle ioy mare
In þis world to weld, þan alle þis ware?
Ffor wha-swa had alle þese, withouten dout,
Had here ioyinoghe, both with-in and without
With alkyn delyces þat he moght have here,
Specialy in alle his wittes sere,
Þat es to say, in syght and hereyng,
And in smellyng, tastyng and feleyng;
Bot yhit alle þir blysses þat yhe herd me neven
War als noght, als to regard to þe blys of heven;
Ffor als mykelle difference, or mare, suld be
Bitwene heven and swilk a ceté,
Als es bitwene a kynges palays
And a swynsty þat es lytelle to prays,
And na mare comparyson may be made
Bitwene þe cité of heven, wyde and brade,
And swilk a ceté made of gold and perré,
Þan bitwene alle þe world and a faulde may be;
Alle-swa alle ryches þat may here be sene
War noght bot als muk þat es unclene,
To regard of þe precyouse rychesce
Of þe ceté of heven þat na man may gesce.
And alle þe melodyse of þe world sere,
War noght bot als sorow to here,
To regard of þe blyssfulle melody
Þat in þe ceté of heven es ay redy.
And alle swete savours þat men may fele,
Of alkyn thing þat here savours wele,
War noght bot als stynk to regard of þat flayre
Þat es in þe ceté of heven swa fayre;
And alle þe worschepe þat here may be,
War noght bot als schendschepe to se,
To regard of þe gret worschepe
Of whilk men salle in heven tak kepe.
Alle þe fairnes þat Absolon had in syght,
War noght bot laythedeMS. Lansd. 348 reads 'filþe'. in heven bryght.
Alle þe strenthe of Sampson þat was pereles,
War noght tald þare bot wayknes.
Alle þe delyces þat had Salomon þe kyng,
War noght in heven bot myslykyng.
Alle þe swyftnes of Assahel þat had he,
War noght þare bot slawnes to se.
Alle þe fredom þat August had whilom,
War noght tald þare bot thraldom.
Alle þe hele þat here had Moyses
War noght tald þare bot als seknes.
Alle þe eld þat Matussale had here,
War les þare þan þe lest day of þe yhere.
Alle þe wisdom þat Salomon had redy
War noght tald þare bot als foly.
Alle þe luf þat David Ionathas lufed,
War noght þare bot als hatereden proved.
Alle þe honoure þat þe Egypciens Ioseph dyd,
War noght in heven bot schendschip kyd.
Alle þe myght þat Alexander had aywhare,
War noght tald bot wayknes þare.
Alle þe acord þat Lisyas had in his lyfe
With Sampson, war þar bot als strife.
Alle þe sykernes þat had Ennoc and Ely
Of þair dwellyng in paradyse, namly,
War noght bot als unsykernes
Of wonyng in heven þat es endles.
Þus may I lyken, als I ymagyn,
Þe ceté of heven and þe blys þare-in,
Tylle a ceté of gold and of precyouse stanes sere
Bot þe ceté of heven es mare bryght and clere,
And es sett on swa heghe a hylle,
Þat na synfulle man may wyn þar-tylle;
Þe whilk hylle I lyken tylle berylle clene,
Þat es clerer þan any þat here es sene;
Þat hille es noght els bi understandyng,
Bot haly thoght and brynand yhernyng,
Þat haly men had here to þat stede,
Whils þai lyfed, bi-for þair dede;
Ffor God wille þat þai als heghe up-pas,
Als þair thoght and yhernyng upward was.
Yhit I lyken, als I ymagyn in thoght,
Þe walles of heven tylle walles þat war wroght
Of alle manere of precyouse stanes sere,
Cymented with gold fulle bryght and clere;
And swa bryght gold ne swa clene,
Was never nane in þis world sene,
Ne swa ryche stanes, ne swa precyouse,
Als obout heven er, ne swa vertuouse.
Þe precyouse stanes, gastly may be
Gud werkes, and þe gold charyté,
Þat obout þase in heven salle schine clere,
Þat dose gud werkes in charyté here.
Þe turrettes of heven, gret and smalle,
I lyken tylle turrettes of clere crystalle;
Bot þe turrettes of heven er mare clere shynand
Þan ever was cristalle in any land.
Þa turrettes, gastly, sere honours may be,
Þat gud men, in heven, salle fele and se.
Þe wardes of þe ceté of heven bryght
I lyken tylle wardes þat war stal worthly dyght
And clenly wroght and craftily tayled
Of clene sylver and gold and enamayld.
Bot þa wardes of þe ceté of heven,
Er mare crafty and strang þam any kan neven,
Bot gastly to speke, þa wardes swa dyght,
May be tald strenthe, and power, and myght,
Þat þas salle have þat in heven salle dwelle,
Als yhe moght here me bifore telle.
Þe yhates I lyken of heven swa brade,
Tylle yhates þat war of charbukelle stanes made
Bot swa clere charbukelle was never sene,
Als þa yhates of heven er ne swa clene;
Bot þa yhates, gastly to speke, er mekenes
And fredom of ryght fayth and bowsomnes,
Þat gyfes way and entré tylle men boghsom,
Intylle þe ceté of heven for to com.
Þe garettes oboven þe yhates bryght
Of þe ceté of heven, I lyken þus ryght,
Tylle þe garettes of a ceté of gold,
Þat wroght war, als I before told,
Of fyne curalle and rych rubys,
And of other stanes of gret prys,
With fyne gold wyre alle obout frett,
And bryght besandes burnyst omang sett.
Þe garettes of heven, gastly, may be
Heghe state, and lordschip, and dignité;
Ffor alle þat salle won in þat ceté þare,
Salle bere heghe state þare-in ever-mare.
Þe lanes alle-swa and þe stretes alle,
Þat in þe ceté of heven may falle,
And þe wonyng-stedes þat er þar-in,
I lyken here, after I ymagyn,
Tylle þe lanes and stretes, less and mare,
Of þe ceté of gold þat I spak of are,
With þe bygynges on ilk syde standand,
Þat of fyne gold war made, bryght schynand;
Bot in na ceté þat men may neven,
Er stedes and lanes swa bryght als in heven;
Ne swa bryght wonyng-stedes als er þar-in,
Can na man, thurgh wytt, ymagyn,
Þe whilk salle schyne, with-in and with-out,
And on ilka syde alle obout,
Whare alle ryghtwyse men salle won at ees,
In ioyfulle quyete, and rest, and pese;
And þarfor haly kyrk, þat oft prays
Ffor þe saules in purgatory, þus says:

L.HI1: Tuam Deus deposcimus pietatem, ut eis tribue|
re digneris lucidas et quietas mansiones.

LG.L: "Loverd God, we ask þi peté,
Þat þou vouche safe, als we pray þe,
To gyf þam wonyng stedes bryght
And restfulle", þat nede has of rest and lyght.
Na bodily eghe moght never here se
A poynt of swilk bryghtnes, als in heven salle be.
Ilka lane in heven and ilka strete
Most schyne bryght, bi skylle, for þar salle mete
Aungels and men bryghter schynand,
Þan ever schane þe son in any land;
Ffor þe body ofilk man salle schyne so bryght
Þat tylle alle a contré, ane moghtgyf lyght;
And ilka hare þare, on þair hede,
And on þair body, on ilka stede,
Salle be als bryght als es þe son,
Þat we may se here whare we won,
Fulle bryght schynand oboven us,
And þarfor says þe boke þus:
"Þe ryghtwis men salle schyne als þe son,"
In heven whare þai salle ever-mare won.
Now sen a ryghtwis man salle schyne als bright
Als þe son dose, þan mon he gyf lyght
Als fer als þe son dose and ferrer,
Fforwhi he salle þan be wele bryghter.
And yhit salle alle þat gret bryghtnes,
Þat ryghtwis men salle have þare be les
Þan þe bryghtnes of God alle-myghty,
Als salle be knawen þare openly,
Ryght als þe sternes here, whare we won,
Semes als to þe bryghtnes of þe son;
Ffor we salle be þare als sternes in bryghtnes,
And God bryghtest als son of ryghtwisnes.
Ilka lane and strete þat in heven may be,
Es lenger þan here es any contré,
Ffor þe roume and þe space þat es contende
In þe ceté of heven has nane ende.
Þa stretes and lanes, gastly to telle,
Er alle haly men þat þare salle dwelle;
And þair wonyngstedes may be þe medes,
Þat þai salle have for þair gud dedes.
In þat ceté salle be mare rychesce
Þan alle þe men of þe world may gesce;
Bot þase ryches gastly to understand,
Er sere blysses and delyces ay lastand,
Þe whilk alle þas, þat tylle heven salle wende,
Salle fele and se þare with-outen ende.
Þe pament of heven may lykened be,
Tille a pament of precyouse stanes and perré;
Bot þe pament of heven salle schyne mar clere
Þan ever schane gold or precyouse stanes here;
And þat pament es sett swa fast,
Þat it salle never fayle bot ay last,
In whilk may na crevyce be sene,
It es swa hale, and even, and clene.
Þis pament of heven als of perré,
Gastly to understand may be
Parfyte luf and lyfe endeles,
With pese, and rest and sykernes,
Þat alle salle have þat salle won þare,
And þis pament salle last ever-mare.
Þus may a man þat kan and wille,
Alle þe ceté of heven lyken bi skylle,
Tylle bodily thing þat es fayre and bryght,
And mast delytabelle here to syght,
And to precyouse stanes of vertow,
And to sylver and gold and thing of valow,
Þat men may here bodily se,
Bot swilk thinges may nane in heven be.
Of verray ryches, gret plenté es þare,
Þat er a hundreth thowsand-fald mare
Þan alle þe ryches of þe world here,
Þat ever was sene, fer or nere,
Þat fayles and passes oway;
Bot þe rychesce of heven salle last ay,
Þat er alle thing, als God vouches save,
Þat men in heven yhernes to have.
Oboven þe ceté of heven salle noght be sene,
Bot bright bemes anly, als I wene,
Þat sal schyne fra Goddes awen face,
And sprede obout and over þat place.
His bright face sal alle þas se,
Þat sal duelle in þat blisful cité;
And þat syght es þe mast ioy of heven,
Als men mught here me byfor neven.
And alle-if þat cité be large and wyde,
Men salle hym se, until þe ferrest syde,
And als wele þas þat sal be fra hym fer,
Als þas þat sal þar til hym be nerrer;
For als men of fer landes may haf sight
Of þe son, þat we se here schyne bright,
And als þe same son þat shynes byyhond þe se
Shewes it here, and in ilka cuntré
Alle þe day, aftir þe ryght course es,
Bot when cloudes fra us hydes hirMS. Harl. 4196 reads 'his'. brightnes;
Right swa þe face of God alle-myghty,
Sal be shewed in heven appertely,
Tille alle þe men þat þider sal wende,
Þogh som suld duelle at þe ferrest ende.
Bot ilk man, als he lufes God here,
Sal won þar, som fer and som nere,
For som lufes God here mar þan sum,
And som lufes hym les þat til heven sal com
Alle þas þat God here lufes best,
When þai com þar sal be hym nerrest,
And þe nerrer þat þai sal hym be,
Þe verreylyer þai sal hym se;
And þe mare verraly þai se his face,
Þe mare sal be þair ioy and solace.
Bot þa þat here lufs hym les,
Þai sal won þar, aftir þair luf es;
Bot ilk man sal se hym in his degré,
In what syde of heven swa he sal be.
Here haf yhe herd of many fayre sight,
Þat ay salle be sene in heven bright;
Ful glade and ioyful alle þas may be,
Þat swilk fayre sightes, ay, þar sal se,
And of mykel ioy may þai ay telle
Þat in þat cité of heven sal ay duelle.
Alswa ilkan sal haf in þair heryng,
Grete ioy in heven and grete lykyng,
For þai sal here þar aungel sang,
And þe haly men sal ay syng omang,
With delitabel voyces and clere;
And, with þat, þai sal ay here
Alle other manere of melody,
Of þe delytable noys of mynstralsy,
And of alkyn swet tones of musyke,
Þat til any mans hert mught like;
And of alkyn noyse þat swete mught be,
Ilkan sal here in þat cité,
With-outen instrumentes ryngand,
And with-outen movyng of mouth or hand,
And with-outen any travayle,
And þat sal never mar cese ne fayle.
Swilk melody, als þar sal be þan,
In þis werld herd never nan erthely man,
For swa swete sal be þat noyse and shille
And swa delitabel and swa sutille,
Þat alle þe melody of þis werld here,
Þat ever has bene herd, fer and nere,
War noght bot als sorowe and care
Als to þe lest poynt of melody þare.
Omang þam alswa sal be swete savour,
Swa swete com never of herbe ne flour,
When þai war in seson mast,
Or war mast of vertu for to tast;
Ne of spicery mught never spryng,
Ne yhit of nan othir thyng,
Þat thurgh vertu of kynde suld savour wele
Swa swete savour als þai sal fele;
For na hert may thynk, ne tung telle,
How swete sal ilkan til other smelle;
Þat savour sal be ful plenteuouse,
And swa swete and swa delicious,
Þat alkyn spicery þat men may fele,
And of alle othir thyng þat here savours wele,
War noght bot als thyng þat stynked sour,
Als to regarde of þat delycious savour.
Þan sal þat savour þat es swa swete,
Be ioy til þam, ay when þai samen mete,
Alswa ilkan þat sal won þar,
Sal syng with angels, als I sayd ar,
In swilk tones þat sal be swete to here,
With ful delitabel voyces and clere;
Bot þai sal love God ay in þair sang,
And thank hym of his mercy ay omang;
And ilkan of þat blisful company
Sal speke with othir þar ful swetely,
With laghyng and with lufly sembland,
And say "weles us þat here er wonnand",
And thank God omang þat þam gun wysse
Til mekenes, þat þam led til þat blysse
With anger þat þai had in þair lyf days,
Þan may þai say þus als David says:
"Loverd ful glad for þe days er we,
In whilk þou made us lawe to be,
In þe yheres in whilk we saw illes."
Þus may þai syng and say for sere skilles.
Þan sal þair sang and þair spekyng,
Be til þam gret ioy and lykyng;
Alswa þai sal fele worshepes grete,
For ilkan sal be sette in a ryche sete,
And, als kynges and qwenes corouned be
With corouns dight with ryche perré,
And with stanes of vertu, precyouse to prays,
Als David til God thus spekes and says:
"Loverd on hys heved þou sette ryght,
A coroune of preciouse stanes dight;"
Bot swa fayre coroune was never sene
In þis world, on kynges heved ne qwene.
Þis coroune es þe coroune of blys,
And þe stane es ioy þat þai sal never mys.
Þis worshepe þat þai sal fele, sal pas
Alle þe worshepes þat ever here was,
Of whilk þai sal þar mar ioy have,
Þan any man can yherne or crave.
Þus sal þai have in þair wittes fyfe
Parfite ioy with endeles lyfe,
In þe heghe blisful cité of heven,
Whar sere ioyes er ma þan tung can neven;
For þai sal many hundreth thowsand se
Of men and wemen in þat cité,
Þat many sere ioyes þar sal haf,
Als þai er worthy and God vouches saf.
And alle þe ioyes þat þai alle sal se,
Sal be ioyes til ilka man þat þar sal be,
With-outen his awen ioyes, les and mare,
Þat til hym-self sal be appropried þare;
For þe sight of ilk ioy þat þai sal se þan,
Sal be ioy þar til ilka man;
For other mens ioyes tham sal like als wele,
Als þai sal þair awen þat þai sal fele;
Þan sal a man haf ma ioyes in heven
Þan any tung couthe telle or neven;
For ilk man sal haf special ioy and mede,
For ilk gude thoght and ilk gude dede,
Þat he ever thoght or wroght open or privé.
Þan may never þair ioys noumbred be,
Þat ilk man in heven when þai com þider
Sal in body and saule haf alle togider,
And never mare of na ioy fele irkyng,
For þai sal ay be new als at þe bigynning,
Of whilk þe leste ioy þar to fele and se,
Sal be mar þan alle þe ioyes of the werld may be
Þai sal be fed þar and cled wele,
With ioy of sight þat þai sal fele,
Þai sal wirk þar nan othir thyng,
Bot love ay God with-outen irkyng,
Als a versifiour says in a verse þarby,
Þe whilk es made in metre þus schortly:
"With þe sight of God þai sal be fed,
And with brightnes of light þai sal be cled,
And þair werk sal be ay lovyng,"
In whilk þai sal haf gret likyng.
Bot þair mast ioy in heven sal be
Þe blisful sight of þe trinité,
Þe whilk þai sal se ever-mar;
And þat ioy sal pas alle othir þar,
For ay whilles þai þat sight sal se,
Of alle ioyes þai sal fulfilled be;
And if þai suld þat syght mysse,
Þai myght noght þan haf parfite blis.
For if a man war pyned in helle,
With ma payns þan tung may telle,
And he of Goddes face mught se oght,
Alle his payns suld þan gryefe hym noght.
Now haf I redde here how men sal hafe
Parfite ioy in heven þat sal be safe;
Bot þe dampned men þar ogayne
Sal haf ful sorowe and parfite payne,
With-outen ende for þair wikked lyfe,
For þai sal in alle þair wittes fyve,
Be turmented on sere manere,
With grysely payns, many and sere,
Þat es to say, in syght and heryng,
In smellyng, tastyng, and felyng.
First þai sal in helle about þam se
Mare sorow þan ever in þis werld mught be,
And þe sorow þat þai sal se þar,
Sal be strang payne til þam ever-mare.
Þair wonyng in helle, als says þe buke,
Þai sal se ful of fire and of smoke,
And ful grysely, and myrk, and dym,
And about þam devels ful grym,
Þat with sere payns sal payne þam ay,
Als men mught here me byfor say:
And alle-þogh þai in helle want light,
Yhit sal pai of alle payns haf sight,
Thurgh þe sparkes of fyr þar, als says Saynt Austyn
Noght til þair comfort bot til þair pyne;
Yhit mare sorow þam sal bytyde,
Þai sal here in helle, on ilka syde,
Ful hydus noyse and duleful dyn
Of devels and of synful men þar-yn:
Þai sal here devels þar, rare ful hydusly,
And þe synful men goule and cry;
Þai sal þar, in smellyng, fele mare stynk,
Þan hert may here ymagyn or thynk,
Of brynnand brunstan and of pyk,
And of alkyn othir thyng þat es wyk.
Þat stynk, als yhe sal understand wele,
Sal be strang payne til þam to fele;
Al-swa þai sal ilkan other wery,
And myssay and sclaundre God allemyghty,
Þai sal ay stryfe and be at debate,
And ilkan other sal despice and hate.
Omang þam sal never be pees,
Bot hatreden and stryfe þat never sal cees.
Þair throtes sal ay be filled omang,
Of alle thyng þat es bitter and strang,
Of lowe and reke with stormes melled,
Of pyk and brunstane togyder welled,
Of molten bras and lede with-alle,
And of other welland metalle:
Þis sal be strang payne til þam to last,
Omang alle othir paynes, lest and mast,
With stryf þat sal be omang þam þan,
When ilkan sal other wery and ban;
Al-swa þai sal fele, als I byfor talde,
Outrageus hete and outrageouse calde,
For now þai sal frese in yse, and now in fire bryn
And be gnawen with-outen and with-in;
Within, als yhe sal understand,
With wormes of conscience ay bytand;
With-outen, with dragons felle and kene,
Swa hidus was never here nane sene,
With neddirs and tades and othir vermyn,
And with many hydus bestes of ravyn,
Als wode wolfes, lyons and beres felle,
Þat sal noght be elles, bot devels of helle,
In liknes of hydus bestes and vermyne,
Þat sal þam gnaw without, to eke þair pyne,
Als in þe sext part of þis boke es wryten.
Þus sal þe synful be gnawen and byten
With outen, thurgh hydus bestes and vermyn,
And thurgh þe worme of conscience with-in.
Þe devels alswa sal stryke þam felly,
With glowand hamers, ful huge and hevy,
Þat sal seme of iren and stele;
Þir payns þai sal with alle other fele.
Þus sal þai ever-mare be pyned þar,
In alle þair fife wittes, als I said ar,
With sere payns als es gode skille,
For þai here used þair wittes ille.
Alle þir payns þat yhe herd me telle,
And many ma þat salle be in helle,
Þai sal thole ay þar þat sal wende þider,
In body and saule alle to-gider.
Þus sal þai ever mar contynuely
Haf parfite payne þar, with-outen mercy,
Fra whilk payne and sorow God us shilde,
Thurgh prayer of hys moder mylde,
And þe right way of lyf us wysse,
Whar-thurgh we may com til heven blysse. Amen.
Now es þe last part of þis buke sped,
And alle þe maters þar-in haf I red,
Þat contenes, als yhe mught here,
Bathe general and special ioyes sere,
Þat alle þas þat til heven sal come,
Sal haf aftir þe day of dome;
And sere schendshepes of helle alswa,
Þat er even contrary til þa,
Þe whilk, þas þat sal til helle wende,
Sal haf þar, with-outen ende.
Whar-for wha-swa of þis wil take hede,
May be stird til luf and drede;
Til drede, thurgh mynde of þe hydusnes
Of payne and sorow þat in helle es;
Til luf, thurgh mynd of ioyes and blisse sere
Þat God hetes til alle þat lufes hym here.
Bot þe drede es noght medeful to prufe,
Þat accordes noght halely with þat lufe;
For if drede stand by itself anely,
Na mede of God it es worthy,
Þarfor drede suld be lufes brother,
And ayther of þam stand with other,
For wha-swa lufes God on ryght manere
He has grete drede to wrethe hym here;
Þan lufes he his bydynges to fulfille,
And dredes to do oght ogayne his wille,
Delites to be with God ay,
And dredes to be put fra hym oway.
For men suld noght drede God anly for payne
Bot men suld drede to tyn þe ioy soverayne,
Þat es, þe syght of God of heven,
Þe whilk yhe herd me byfor neven;
ÞatÞan (MS. Harl. 4196.) es pat luf ay with þat drede,
And þat dred of God es worthy mede,
For þogh we suld never helle se,
Ne [for] syn suld never punyst be,
In purgatory ne in helle,
Ne in þis werld whar we duelle,
Yhit suld we luf God for hym-self ryght,
And drede to tyne hys luf and of him þe syght,
For, sikerly I dar wele say þis,
Þat wha-swa wyst what ioy and blys
Of þe syght of God in heven war,
And als proprely had sene it als es þar,
He had lever thole here þis payne,
Ilk day anes, alle qwikThe MS. reads 'qwilk'. to be flayne,
Ar he þe syght of his face suld tyne,
Þat in heven so bright sal shyne.
Many sere ioys ma þar sal falle,
Bot þat sight es mast principalle ioy of alle;
For þat ioyful sight sal contene
Alle other ioyes þat sal þar be sene,
Of whilk ioys, þe lest sal pas
Alle þe ioy þat ever here was.
For ioy here es noght bot passand vanité,
Bot þe ioyes þat er þar ever-mar sal be,
Til whilk ioyes þat has nan ende,
God us bring when we hethen wende. Amen.
Now haf I here als I first undir-toke,
Fulfilled þe seven partes of þis boke,
Þat er titeld byfor to have in mynde.
Þe first es of þe wrechednes of mans kynde;
Þe secunde es of þe werldes condicions sere,
And of þe unstabelnes of þe werld here;
Þe thred es of þe ded þat es bodily;
Þe ferthe alswa es of purgatory;
Þe fift es of domesday, þe last day of alle,
And of þe takens þat byfor sal falle;
Þe sext es of þe paynes of helle to neven;
And þe sevend part es of þe ioyes of heven.
In þir seven er sere materes drawen
Of sere bukes, of whilk som er unknawen,
Namly til lewed men of England,
Þat can noght bot Inglise undirstand;
Þarfor þis tretice drawe I wald
In Inglise tung þat may be cald
Prik of Conscience als men may fele,
For if a man it rede and understande wele,
And þe materes þar-in til hert wil take,
It may his conscience tendre make,
And til right way of rewel bryng it bilyfe,
And his hert til drede and mekenes dryfe,
And til luf and yhernyng of heven blis,
And to amende alle þat he has done mys.
For þe undirstandyng of þir maters seven,
Þat men may in þis buke se and neven,
May make a man knawe and halde in mynde,
What he es here of his awen kynde,
And what he sal be, if he avyse hym wele,
And whar he es, for to knaw and fele.
Yhit may he se when he it redes
What he es worthy for his dedes,
Whether he es worthy ioy or payne
Þis tretice may make hym be certayne,
For þar-in may he many thynges se,
Þat has bene, and es, and þat sal be;
Þus may þis tretice, with þe sentence,
Pryk and stirre a mans conscience,
And til mekenes and luf and drede it dryfe,
For to bring hym til ryght way of lyfe.
Of alle þeis I haf sere maters soght,
And in seven partes I haf þam broght,
Als es contende in þis tretice here,
Þat I haf drawen out of bukes sere,
Aftir I had in þam understandyng,
Alle-if I be of symple kunnyng.
Bot I pray yhou alle, par charité,
Þat þis tretice wil here or se
Yhe haf me excused at þis tyme,
If yhe fynde defaut in þe ryme,
For I rek noght, þogh þe ryme be rude,
If þe maters þar-of be gude.
And if any man þat es clerk,
Can fynde any errour in þis werk,
I pray hym he do me þat favour,
Þat he wille amende þat errour;
For if men may here any errour se,
Or if any defaut in þis tretice be,
I make here a protestacion,
Þat I wil stand til þe correccion
Of ilka rightwyse lered man,
Þat my defaut here correcte can.
Þis tretice specialy drawen es
For to stirre lewed men til mekenes,
And to make þam luf God and drede;
Ffor wha-swa wil it here or rede,
I hope he sal be stirred þar-by.
Yf he trow þat God es alle-myghty,
And he sal it here or se,
And may noght þar-by stirred be,
It semes þat he es wittles,
Or over mykel hardend in wikkednes.
Bot alle þas þat redes it, loud or stille,
Or heres it be red with gode wille,
God graunt þam grace þat þai may
Be stird þar-by til ryghtwyse way,
Þat es, tille þe way of gude lyfyng,
And at þe last be broght til gude endyng.
And yhe þat has herd þis tretice red
Þat now es broght til ende and sped,
For þe luf of our Loverd Ihesu,
Pray for hym specialy þat it dru,
Þat if he lyf, God safe hym harmles,
And mayntene hys lyf in alle gudenes,
And if he be ded, als falles kyndely,
God of his saule haf mercy,
And bryng it til þat blisful place
Whar endeles ioy es and solace,
Til whilk place he us alle bryng,
Þat for us vouched safe on rode to hyng. Amen.
LG.TRAILER: Explicit tractus qui dicitur, Stimulus Consciencie. Here endes þe tretice þat es called Pryk of Conscience.
